story:
Hi! Let me introduce myself first before telling why I’m asking you for your support:

I am Gregorius Kuijlenburg or Joeri for short.

I grew up in Sassenheim in the Flower District of the Netherlands. I currently live in Amsterdam, studying Fine Art and Education. This semester I will be getting my Bachelor's degree. In 2011, I studied at the Pratt Institute in New York for a semester and it was a life changing experience. My goal was "to go back to my roots" and do what I love the most: Drawing. It has always been my favorite medium and I use photography as a part of my creative process. l also love passing on my knowledge, inspiration and enthusiasm to a young audience, through teaching fine art and connecting with art in a meaningful way.

Your Support

I have recently been granted my green card, so I am very excited to have made the decision to move to the US to start a new life there, a new adventure full of opportunity. To make the transition possible, l need at least € 2000. Since the authorities expect me to be living in the US by May 21st, there is only a small window of time for me to organize and fund everything. Therefore, your support would help to pay for my travel expenses and allow me to settle in during the first few weeks after my arrival as I set new goals for the future: Ultimately establish myself as an artist, which I would love to combine with teaching fine art and inspire a young audience. That is when I am most happy and at my best! Your support would definitely help me realize these goals.

What I offer in exchange

As a token of my gratitude, I will send you a signed drawing in pen, ink and graphite on archival paper, which I will make especially for this fundraiser in exchange for your support. You will receive your art work soon after I make my way to the US.

I will miss the Dutch skies, but will bring them along with me, wandering towards new horizons, through a swallow's calligraphy.

Thank you for your help and support and please share this project with others!

Gregorius, Joeri


www.kuijlenburg.eu

story:
Bringing the Boston School style of painting to Cheshire County! The future Sheldon Studio hopes to provide instruction and studio space to aspiring artists in Southern N.H.


The Objective

To provide aspiring artists with the tools, space, and training to learn to draw and paint. Christopher Sheldon seeks to provide this training and space to students at the lowest rate possible. The tuition rate will be set by the maintenance of the studio, utilities, and model fees. A studio space in better location, with communally held costs will allow him to better focus on his own painting and as such he is willing to teach students without recieving any monetary compensation.

THE MAN BEHIND THE STUDIO

Growing up in the depressed shop town of Troy, NH, Christopher Sheldon now sees an opportunity to bring the arts and revenue into his community by starting his own a atelier there. The dream is this: to create studio space for a small group of students and then: Inhabit! Create! Teach! Learn!

He's spent the last 6 years using the now defunct Troy Blanket Mill as a studio space but the size and current state of disrepair are impractical for his purposes. A new space must be found.

This month a historic power station has been put up for sale on Route 12, which runs straight through the little town. With minimal remodeling this building would be an ideal location for the future Sheldon Studio. The space is suitably modest and the site is accessible and situated where commuters will have the opportunity to watch the project grow.

MONEY MAKES THE WORLD GO AROUND

Funding for the project will be employed both in the purchase of the building and the restructuring of the Northern pitch of the roof, to capture the perfect lighting conditions for aspiring oil painters. Inside the front room which has been designated 'studio space' will be re-painted and partitioned into bays for the students.

SHOOTING HIGH

The project is designed to create a studio where students can get classical training at a minimum rate. Sheldon would not be extracting any fees and would in essence be teaching for free. The tuition required would go exclusively to the maintence of studio, classes, model fees, and other basic necessities.

Any extra money raised will be put toward tuition of low income students, on a basis of artistic merit and financial need. Our dreams are sometimes hobbled by our credit or our debt, as we attempt to raise money for Christopher's dream we are mindful of the aspirations of others who may need help.

SHOOTING LOW

If the goal is not met we may be able to combine the funds gathered with a loan to make up the difference. In the event that the Power Station slips from our grasp, the dream of Sheldon Studio will live on in the next suitable location we can find. We are always on the look out for appropriate real estate in Cheshire County.

The institution of this atelier will not only bring interest and attention into the town of Troy, it will provide an outlet for creators in the area, as well as instruction and a safe forum in which to connect with other artists.

In recent years New Hampshire has seen a mass exodus of the young. Job opportunities across the country are drawing our generation away. We would like to stay and make our home here, start and run our businesses here, and provide the resources that may also encourage others to contribute to our community.

story:
hey there!  my name is jen, but many of you may know me by me business name - "ginger snappy gems".  

i have been making hand crafted jewelry for a couple years, and my tiny business has grown into a proud small business.  

i am currently doing all of my jewelry work on a desk made from tv tables from the 70s (i remember watching happy days while eating dinner on them), and plywood.    my supplies are everywhere, my scraps have taken over the floor and my tools... i just cant even find them most days!  

i need a REAL jeweller's bench.

the problem is, i have more jewelry making time and supplies than i do cash flow, im hoping that we can make a trade!  the workbench is 700$, but im asking for just 500$.

please check out my work:  

- https://www.facebook.com/GingerSnappyGems

- shop.gingersnappygems.com

then, check out the incentives im offering

and finally, make a pledge!

thank you xo

story:
We need your help!

Earthy Arts will be a folk art school and retreat center that provides access to learning the "old ways" of doing things. In addition to teaching traditional crafts, we will offer instruction in traditional food arts and have outdoor spaces for teaching other skills such as dying fiber, herb gathering, gardening/canning, etc.

 
Earthy Arts is dedicated to providing a learning and retreat space that promotes both art and love of the earth…filling a gap of artistic enrichment in McLeod County (Minnesota) and providing retreat space for anyone from anywhere. 
 
We need your help to make this vision a reality! 
 
The first $75,000 will go to purchase the building. The additional funds will be for perks, 501c3 establishment, equipment for the school, renovating the main floor and finishing the upstairs retreat space. It will also help provide basic operation costs for the first few months.

story:
About "...journeyed many miles..."

tangential ghosts 
hazy youth
a cluster of headaches and enjoyments 

On May 4th, 2013 venture to Ho_se for a night of writing, art, and music. 

28 Lawton St #1, Brooklyn, New York 11221

QUIET SONS
https://www.facebook.com/QUIETSONS

FEATURING: 

Blake Andrews
Elina Ansary 
Max Branigan 
Evan Bender 
Jenni Crain 
Annaliese Downey
James Gentile 
Adam Johnson 
Chris Jones 
Miles Joyner
Laura Knetzger
Jennifer Lin
Jaclyn Miller 
Annie Paradis 
Olivia Russin 
Vreni Stollberger 
Bebe Strnad 
Joseph Sutton 
Heidi Systo

 

What We Need

We will be showing at the glorious venue called Ho_se, 28 Lawton St #1, Brooklyn, New York. Ho_se is wonderful for fledglings, because the coordinators have a special interest in affordability and accessibility. The show space is the basement and back yard of a brownstone. Believe it or not, they're generously asking only $100 for the night. This helps them cover the cost of an attendant and various maintenance. 

Sometimes people (always) like to go to shows and drink. Some prefer wine. Others will likely reach a hand into their jacket and pull out a flask of rubbing alcohol. "...journeyed many miles..." would like to provide a healthy choice between PBR and PBR. This is an important part of our budget, the booze. Upwards of $100 will do the trick. Every good show needs a bar, and you can help! 

We are slapping a fresh coat of paint on the space a few nights before this show. Paint, no matter how basic, is expensive and requires some accoutrements. Nails, hammers, tape, etc are necessary as well. $200 will help to offset the cost of painting and installation. 

We may need to provide transportation for artists and their artwork, especially on installation day. $100 should help cover any emergency cab rides. It's never fun to carry a canvas through the wind and rain. 

If we exceed our goal or don't use all the money, extra donations go towards food. Artists are starving and pizza in our volume of consumption aint cheap. 

Perks!

Check out our many perks in the upper right of this page. No good deed goes unnoticed. 

Why This is Important

Artists, writers, musicians, and creative people in general need to show their madness to the world. It's difficult to do. Events like "...journeyed many miles..." are self curated and accessible to the public. They offer new opportunities to the participants and viewers. This exhibition is just one of many conversations concerning life and meaning. You can be a part of the process by donating. We guarantee you will not find a more appreciative crowd. 

If your pockets are empty but your heart is full, donate your time and skills instead. We can always use an extra hand! Email journeyedmanymiles@gmail.com for details.

story:
For Zonotopia 2012 please go to Zonotopia and the Two Trees

 

---This is our 2011 campaign---

For two years now the wondrous Zomes of Zonotopia have revealed themselves on the Playa at Burningman. ??

 

Rob Bell creates Zomes: a magical, fantasy like architecture combining art, engineering and love into a series of pavilion-like structures. Like enormous radiolaria the Zomes seem to be enigmatic artifacts from a mythic age long ago. Each year more secrets from this bygone epoch are revealed and each year Zonotopia grows to further enchant people with its solemn, transcendent, spiritual quality.

In 2011 Zonotopia returns, and we need your help to pay for materials and transportation to the playa. Zonotopia is constructed entirely from sustainably harvested wood using state of the art digital fabrication tools and plenty of hand work to create a warm, natural and aesthetically harmonious proportion of form and function. The design, fabrication and construction is a 100% labor of love by the team.

We have a proven track record of delivering.??

In 2009, Rob Bell and Patricia Algara built the Bodhisattva Zome. Immensely popular, this beautiful eight frequency Zome pavilion has charmingly been referred to as a Princess Gazebo. This Zome has been assembled and enjoyed eight times proving the enduring quality of the system and the design.???

In 2010, Rob and Patricia with the help of Mission Country Club brought the Bodhisattva back now accompanied by the new and significantly more complex and larger Zonotopia Zome: a twelve frequency wonder. With a more advanced joinery system, painted white and illuminated with blacklights by night; the Zonotopia Zome fascinated and astounded everyone with it's beautiful proportion and attention to detail from near and far. From weddings to yoga to dance parties this Zome provided a stunning space for experiences to happen.

?

And now in 2011, in addition to the return the previous Zomes and some new charming zome siblings we will bring the true power and magic of Zomes forth from the playa in the form of a 40' tall twisting Zome tower to create a true zonohedral wonderland. The structure will be securely anchored to the playa and will be solid and safe for climbers. Inside there will be ample seating, a DJ and dance area and rigging for aerial acrobatic performances.

The astounding modular beauty of the Zome system means that once we begin production the more panels we can fabricate the more amazing art we can bring to the playa. All additional funds beyond our goal will create more magic in this zonohedral wonderland of inspiration and imagination. There are more zonohedral wonders under the Sun and the Moon yet to be seen.

You can help Zonotopia, this Once and Future Utopia of Zomes, rise again and prove that good design and beautiful architecture need not be a high-end commodity.

zome mani padme zome

Rob Bell

story:
Short Summary

Universe Revolves Around YOU is a new work by sculptor Zachary Coffin - a 30' merry go round made of granite and steel, slated to be built for Burning Man 2012. 

Universe is a work about inertia. The idea is to create a plaything, an object that allows YOU to interact with rolling mass equivalent to a loaded railroad freight car. In this case, the load is big slabs of stone, spinning boulders and a lot of humans.

This human-powered merry go round will have a moving weight of about 80,000lbs, plus people.  The ring will be surfaced with thick slabs of granite and two kinetic elements will add or subtract energy from the spinning ring. All mass in motion.

The total cost of building this piece is estimated at about $94,000. We've raised nearly $60,000, which leaves us with a total of $34,000 to raise. We are hoping to raise $17,000 through Kickstarter, and will gladly accept more. Thank you for checking out our project! Please share with your friends!

 

What We Need & What You Get

We need cash to build the piece. We will set you up with awesome swag, and if you're going to Burning Man this year, some amazing experiences.

The Impact

Keep an artist from going into serious debt. 

Other Ways You Can Help

Tell your friends! Spread the word!

story:
Our Story

Wishwas, meaning “faith” is a non-profit organization whose mission is to help empower underprivileged women prosper and gain economic independence. Wishwas will provide education, training and micro-credit/micro-finance loans to disadvantaged women, especially those from the South Asian communities. It will focus on leadership development, communication skills, relationship management, personal finance management, and entrepreneurship development among diverse women and help them with their personal and professional advancement


We  empower the South Asian women who are first generation immigrants in the New York City. Some of them lack language skills and are stay at home moms. The cultural barriers unable the South Asian women to financially make their own choices, have their own say in important matters that affect their lives.


*Give them tools , skills like sewing, food handling, jewelry making, crafts, design , marketing and leadership  though training and workshops.


*Visits from social workers volunteering to teach the women about reproductive health and other related diseases and issues.


* Conduct various immigration law workshops for immigrants who are struggling with their status here, get them free legal help by bringing in people who volunteer and are dedicated to the issue of the immigrants.


* Educate women on their rights and facilities,Help them to pursue High School education through GED programs, give them conversational skills through ESOL programs.

The Impact

This project has an impact on women who will earn their living by learning the basics of working in cooperatives gaining immense financial freedom. This will not only enhance their self esteem but entrepreneurial skills resulting in empowerment and freedom.

What We Need & What You Get

We need sewing machines

20sewing machines -$299 each


20 surgers-$300 each


sewing materials-$1000


fabrics,embellishments,trimmings  $500


Craft materials $500


If you cannot donate money, you can donate machines and materials for us, also, the money you want to put for them in cooperatives could be funded as small loans if they want to start their own design lines.

Other Ways You Can Help

(Unleash the DIWO! -- 'Do It With Others' by asking folks to get the word out and make some noise about your campaign. Don't forget to remind them about the share tools!)

story:
I have been accepted as a partially-funded Fellow, to participate in a month-long artist’s residency in Otranto, Italy this June. There are only 12 artists and architects per year who are accepted to the BAU Institute Residency, and funding is scarce. I received $500 Euros, which translates to just $626.25 US dollars. If I am able to raise funds, I will have the extraordinary opportunity to live and work on the coast of the Adriatic Sea - what a dream! I will have the chance to meet and form possible collaborations and connections with other international artists and critics, and be immersed in a culturally rich and incredibly historical setting.

 

Going to Italy has always been a dream and if I had a longer period of time to plan and raise funds by working, painting, and saving, I would not need as much assistance; however, I was notified just two days ago. Therefore, I am asking for help with travel costs, as well as living costs not covered by the Institute. Any donation will be greatly appreciated, and your generosity will be compensated with a work of art from me!

 

I will also continue to post small paintings for seven-day auctions on my blog:

http://www.kristinbeaver.blogspot.com/

Here is my website:

http://www.kristinbeaver.com/

 

Thank you in advance for your support!

 

Sincerely,

Kristin Beaver
story_txt:
I have been accepted as a partially-funded Fellow, to participate in a month-long artist’s residency in Otranto, Italy this June. There are only 12 artists and architects per year who are accepted to the BAU Institute Residency, and funding is scarce. I received $500 Euros, which translates to just $626.25 US dollars. If I am able to raise funds, I will have the extraordinary opportunity to live and work on the coast of the Adriatic Sea - what a dream! I will have the chance to meet and form possible collaborations and connections with other international artists and critics, and be immersed in a culturally rich and incredibly historical setting.
 
Going to Italy has always been a dream and if I had a longer period of time to plan and raise funds by working, painting, and saving, I would not need as much assistance; however, I was notified just two days ago. Therefore, I am asking for help with travel costs, as well as living costs not covered by the Institute. Any donation will be greatly appreciated, and your generosity will be compensated with a work of art from me!
 
I will also continue to post small paintings for seven-day auctions on my blog:
http://www.kristinbeaver.blogspot.com/
Here is my website:
http://www.kristinbeaver.com/
 
Thank you in advance for your support!
 
Sincerely,
Kristin Beaver

story:
Jeff's Going to Colombia!

Hey Everyone!

I'm very excited to let you know that this December I will be going to Medellin, Colombia to serve on a Mission Trip with 25 other Young Adults from the Cumberland Presbyterian Church.  I will be serving in a leadership position on this trip.

The goal of this trip is to put on a conference for our mission Presbyteries in Colombia.  I will be serving as a conference organizer and trainer on community organizing.  I was chosen to be a leader on this trip because of my experience as a community organizer.  As you know, I worked for the last 5 years as a community organizer in politics.  I learned so much about community involvement in that time and saw the benefits that it can bring.  

I will be working on training materials and curriculum for community organizing sections of this conference.  The Cumberland Presbyterian Church selected me as a leader for this Mission Trip because of these skills and I accepted this position because of my passion for community organizing.  

Not only is this trip a chance to bring community organizing skills to the people of Colombia, it is a trip that connects me with my family.  

 

As some of you know, my Grandfather, Dr. William T. Ingram Jr., was a Cumberland Presbyterian Minister and President of the Memphis Theological Seminary.  He had a great passion for mission work and he travelled to Colombia to help with the setting up of our mission Presbyteries in Colombia.  He also helped found the Seminary in Medellin, Colombia.  As part of my trip I will be making a visit to this Seminary.  

As you can see, this trip is very special and important to me.  I believe in the work that I will be doing there and this place also has a special significance to me and my family.  I hope that you will consider contributing and supporting me on this trip.

What We Need & What You Get

Alright, so let's get down to business.  Here is what I will need for this trip.

My fundraising goal is $2,500.  This will go towards my:

  • Travel To and From Medellin, Colombia 
  • Lodging and Travel While in Medellin
  • Conference Administrative Costs (Materials, Location, Food)

I encourage you to give whatever you feel you can.  Whether it is $5 or $500, I appreciate all of the support you can give and you should know that your money is going to a worthwhile cause.

With that being said, I will be doing some special things for people that give certain amounts.

$10- A personal thank you note from me.

$25- A personal thank you note from me, plus a gift straight from Colombia!

$50- A personal thank you note from me, access to the trip blog, and a Captain Colombia T-Shirt.  Design Below:

 

Anyone that gives $75 or more will get to discuss with me some additional options.  I can't offer too much in the way of other things, but I also want to encourage you to give as much as you feel comfortable giving.

The Impact

Community organizing has a tremendous impact on the communities that understand how to use it.  I train people to empower themselves and their communities to take action.  This is the impact that I hope to bring to our Prebytery in Colombia.  To train people on how to reach out to their community to solve problems in their community by using their collective power. 

The purpose is to give church leaders the sense that they can have an impact on their community.  They don't have to confine themselves to the four walls of their churches.  They have a world of opportunity outside of those walls to make a difference in their community.

The Impact for me personally is also high.  I have been interested in my Grandfather and Father's trips to Colombia and I value that experience.  It would be immensely important to me on a personal level to be the 3rd generation of my family to go to Colombia.  Below are a couple of photos of my Grandfather on his first trip to Colombia.

Other Ways You Can Help

I get it.  You can't always give money to support.  You may not have the ability to give money, but you do have personal networks that you can reach out to as well.  

If you believe in me and what I want to accomplish with this mission trip, I hope that you will be able to communicate with others to help me out.  Here are a few ways that you can help out if you cannot financially support me.

  • Pray or send good thoughts to me while I go on this journey.
  • Send the link to this Indiegogo campaign to your friends that would want to help.

However you decide to help, know that I appreciate it and your efforts to help me out will not go to waste.

story:
Artists of New Mexico Galleria

          

Help over 200 Artists succeed with your generous support.

We need you more than ever to join our TEAM -      Shop, Share, Bring your Friends & Donate

-Thank you from all of us here at AoNM

It started with an empty former community center and Artists of New Mexico founders Amalie and Bambi’s vision of a permanent arts and crafts market where handcraft artists like themselves could operate a storefront and sell their work. The Artists of New Mexico Galleria started on a shoe-string budget and was launched within months through the dedicated efforts of the many volunteers who believed in their vision. With both Amalie’s and Bambi’s life savings and hundreds of hours of volunteer work and donated materials they transformed the empty gym and facility into a vibrant home for the arts in downtown Albuquerque. 

 

The Artists of New Mexico Galleria now represents over 200 artists of all kinds. Artists have the option to setup their store on a weekly, monthly or multi-month basis, allowing them to have an inexpensive permanent location with internet access, clean facilities and heating/cooling. Artists can also elect to have their work included in the Galleria Consignment Shop if they cannot be here, due to family and job responsibilities. You’ll frequently find Bambi working in the Consignment Shop. Each month we also have between 18-25 small businesses and artists set-up their booths and tables to sell their work. Our small café, Cosmic Euphoria, specializes in heart-healthy deserts, lunches, snacks, & beverages. The café owner Tami is also a very talented mixed-media artist. The Galleria also has a classroom area available for reservations for classes, workshops and conferences. The outside grounds of the Galleria features a community garden and a children’s playground. Every weekend the Galleria hosts live entertainment by local bands and schedules a community event each month.

Artists of New Mexico Galleria artists include: 

  • Fireworks Jewelry by Amalie

  • Bamble's Jewelry

  • V. Isenhower Photography

  • Caricatures by Andy

  • Jewelry by Seraphim

  • Silk by Brooke

  • The Tole Way, New Mexico 3-D Art/Papertole, 3-D Art

  • Cosmic Euphoria Cafe

  • Creations by Charlene

  • Hardwood Furniture by Mel

  • Southwest Interiors

  • Victorian Gifts & More

  • Sleeping Dog Design's

  • Willa's Art Attic

  • G's Things

  • Yin Yan Designs

  • Art Glass Magic

  • Ancient Art & Energy

  • Estole Astrology & Tarot

  • Listen for Joy

  • This Calls for Confetti

  • Art by Hauie

  • Chvotzkin Art

  • Southwest Ceramic Lighting

  • Ron Schwartz Scenics

  • Catspaw

  • Circle of Hope

  • Southwest Summers

  • Select Woodcraft

  • Humming Bird Creations

  • Papa Don Pottery

  • Gypsy Thunder

  • Zoe's Nail Products

  • And many more!

 

These are just a few of the artists, performers, and musicians that come in and utilize this great space in a safe, family-oriented and community based environment.

IndiGoGo Campaign:

The Artists of New Mexico Galleria needs your support to continue to grow. Operating this facility requires a myriad of little things that add up fast. Your donations will be used to:

  • Hold classes & workshops on business and trade operations for artists, art appreciation and art instruction
  • Begin a walking art tour connecting our Galleria with our neighbors in Old Town and the Museum of Art 

  • Finish the mural of hot air balloons around the sign

  • Plant this year's community garden

  • Fix the Flag Pole and finish repairs around the building to make the back rest area wheelchair accessible

  • Help pay the bills like the rent, power, gas, water, & garbage

We know we can make this wonderful place work. We just need a little more time and you.

We are offering many very nice perks for your donations – prints, jewelry and original works of art. Top contributors will receive a hot air balloon ride in Albuquerque, hotel and private reception in your honor at the Galleria. The more you are able to contribute to our cause the more artwork you will receive as a HUGE THANK YOU!!! Check them out, and please look at the photo Gallery.

We have worked hard and will continue to do so. We are very proud of what we have all built and now need your help to keep it going.  You may also contact us if you are an artist looking for a place to show and sell. We LOVE ART, all forms of artwork are welcome and we would love to see what you have to offer the wonderful world of art.

If you cannot make a monetary contribution, that's okay. There are so many ways you can still help. You can volunteer at the Galleria or donate materials and supplies. You can help us spread the word and make as much noise as you can about our campaign, use the share tools on this site, visit Artist's of New Mexico Galleria, Go to our Facebook page and support us in the social media world. We truly appreciate any and all that you and the other volunteers do to keep this going.

THANK YOU from the TEAM here at Artists of New Mexico & Beyond Galleria.

More About AoNM

 

Artists of New Mexico & Beyond Galleria is a wonderful group of artists, musicians, performance artists, teachers, families, & so much more. AONM was created by Amalie Dorn and Bambi Cordova. They started working together in the year 2000 as waitresses at a restaurant. They each have 3 children and were looking for a way to support their kids from home. Amalie started Fireworks Jewelry and Bambi started Bamble's Jewelry. Their next step was to sell their unique designs at small arts and craft shows. One year they decided to rent a small tent and invite other artists to join them as vendors at the Albuquerque International Balloon Fiesta. It was a success!

In 2008 Amalie and Bambi were given the opportunity to expand their art show at the Balloon Fiesta. They became the promoters of the only arts and crafts show at Balloon Fiesta. Artists of New Mexico & Beyond was born. They have grown that business from a 12,000 square foot show to an over 20,000 square foot show in just 4 short years. In the meantime, both women continued to work hard designing and selling their own jewelry.

As Amalie and Bambi got to know the other artists they learned that many of them did not have a permanent venue to show and sell their work. The two women started looking for the perfect place to house all of this wonderful handcrafted artwork. They came across an historic building built in 1954 as the Old Town Albuquerque Boy's and Girl's club. The building, which had served many young people, now sat empty. After not being used for years it was in need of repair and love.

In February of 2012 Amalie and Bambi leased the building thus creating the new Artists of New Mexico & Beyond Galleria. Everyone knew it was important for us to respect and restore as much of the original building and signage as we could. Check out the gallery pics to see some of the people and work done. We had to move fast and open the doors by April 5th, 2012. A call was set out to all of the artists from the craft shows, family, friends, co-workers and we talked to local members of the community. Everyone came through with an amazing response. We literally had hundreds of volunteers show up to donate their time, materials, supplies, flowers, seeds and even food for those who were working so hard to get it done.

Many people who came in called us crazy; they said it was impossible and simply couldn't be done. We looked at them, asked for their help and said, "many hands make light work." We continued on with determination living into our slogan “TEAM” (Together Everyone Achieves more).

Everyone worked toward a common goal of helping others make it. All the workers and supporters believed that where there is a will, there is a way in all that you do. We worked 18-20 hour days, 7 days a week. The deadline was coming up fast and we still had so much to do. The pressure was intense for some and pushed others to work harder. Finally, on April 5, 2012 the Albuquerque Chamber of Commerce hosted our Artists of New Mexico & Beyond Galleria's Grand opening ceremony.

We did it thanks to all of those volunteers. Many artists now have a permanent home to share and sell their artwork.

Rivkela Brodsky with the Albuquerque Journal came to interview Bambi Cordova. She was excited about the space and all of the people so dedicated to making it work. Rivkela wrote an article which was published in the Business Outlook section of the Albuquerque Journal on May 7, 2012. To see the article look in the gallery of pictures above. One of the artists, Leo Atreides who is also a filmmaker, was so excited he created a 2 minute commercial for AONM which ran on channel 7 – watch it on YouTube: http://youtube.com/watch?v=zZMyImgLYp8 to see it.

We advertise with a small ad in ABQ ARTS Magazine and with a small ad in the Alibi.

We have another artist Alane Cole who is also a graphic designer. She helped create our website: http://artistsofnm.com  She also designed and printed our business cards, postcards, banners, & helped launch our Facebook page: https://www.facebook.com/Artistsofnm Visit our Facebook page where we have many pictures of the artwork, artists and loads of information and links.

We need your help

We need your help to continue on our journey to keep all of these hardworking artists in a permanent community based space. Bambi and Amalie have given it all they have financially. Each of them have both gone through their savings and yet are still willing to get their hands dirty and work hard. We have volunteers lined up waiting to do anything they can to help. Currently, all they can do is continue talking about us and getting people in to see what a wonderful place this is. A couple of our members Nona and Don Church even donated neon lights for the outside and made a donation to start a mural on the outside of the building plus they are the ones to thank for the lovely gardens we have blooming out front and the productive community garden.

If you are in the neighborhood come over and check us out we'd love to give you the tour & tell you all about ourselves!  See you soon!

THANK YOU!!!!!!!!

We've got our hands & souls in this because we believe in our community!  

Together Everyone Achieves More - TEAM Work motto

    

Cosmic Euphoria Desserts & Art

Artisanal Cafe & Bakery

Delicious & healthy desserts, cookies, salads, sandwiches & soups even fresh juices & teas

Our beautiful community garden and rest area - we even have a fabulous play area for the kids donated by Home Depot! 

                   

Live entertainment almost every weekend by local musicians & performers.

          Artists of New Mexico & Beyond proudly support charities such as Casa Esperanza as it is very important to us to give back when we are able.

                      

You might even find some of our artist members getting inspired

story:
Title: The Workshop that GoGo built

Our Story

We are a local family business that wants to help serve our community. We are focused on bringing people together to share a common interest. . Our ultimate goal is to have a full service yarn shop that is family friendly.  In the meantime we  are going to start that process by finishing off our new workshop. As you can see from the picture, it needs work! We will not be contracting out any of the work. 

The Impact

If this campaign is successful it will allow us to ramp up production and shorten wait times for custom dyed yarns. It will also get the dye work out of our kitchen, which is very important. 

We are, as far as we know, the only dyer to offer yarns made to order in whatever colors the customer requests. We also offer yarns based on themes. Some examples of those would be “I love the 80’s”, “My Little Ponies” and yarn inspired by Charlie and the Chocolate Factory. This campaign will also allow us to have a sock of blank yarn to dye from, and chemicals (which will lessen wait time). We are also excited that in addition to offering rovings and batts we would love to start making hand felted wool or wool blend fedoras.

 

What We Need & What You Get

We are looking for $3500  to renovate the studio space and make it comfortable and inviting. Where is the money going??? We realize that the cost of the materials are probably off. The funds raised will be distributed first to finish the shop, then to supplies. Shelving will be last.

If we are so fortunate to get $1000 over our goal, we will donate $500.00 of that to West Claremont Center for Music and the Arts. This will apply to each $1000.00 over goal we raise, so you help twice!  

Here is an outline of what we still need:

  • Flooring $160

  • Drywall $100

  • Insulation $100

  • Cooktop $400

  • utility sink $100

  • Cabinets and counter $700

  • 6 steel shelves $300

  • 2 wire shelve sets $50

  • Stock yarn (Few different bases) $1500

    • Fingering

    • DK

    • Worsted/Aran

  • Hat forms $100

 

What you get for your help?

$5 Thank you card with a photo of the completed studio

$10-10% off a one time order

$15- 15% off a one time order

$20-Knitting pattern by one of our friends

$25-Scarf kit, or gift certificate (please specify knit or woven)

$50- One skein of hand spun or dyed yarn by Galloping Jester, or gift certificate

$50- 15oz Galloping Jester logo coffee mug

$80- Woven scarf

$100- Small Galloping Jester reusable tote

$100-free workshop (dying, spinning, felting)

$250- Woven shawl

$500-Your choice of knitting kit

$500-Felted Fedora

$1000-lifetime 25% discount off lessons, knit items and yarns.

 

Other Ways You Can Help

We can always use help in the workshop with construction. Help at shows, markets and festivals. Word of mouth is key. Tell your friends where to get one of a kind yarn and woven items!

Please also check out West Center for Music and the Arts: http://www.wcc-ma.org/aboutus/#.Ua09sNLVB8E

About them:

The West Claremont Center for Music and the Arts’ (WCCMA) mission is to bring professional music and arts experiences, diverse musicians, and educational opportunity to the underserved and low-income community of Claremont NH, and wider region. We are committed to offering performances and workshops without charge, enabling everyone in the community to access the arts and their benefits. WCCMA offers amazing performances, youth arts education, instrument borrowing for low income families, artist networking, community workshops, and more.

 Please pass this link onto your friends! Any donation is much appreciated and a little goes a long way.

story:
Short Summary

YorkSlam is the first-ever poetry slam series in York Region. During our inaugural season this year, we brought together people from across the entire region to experience the amazing art form of spoken word. In June we formed a team to represent the Region at the national slam championships this October in Saskatoon. The goal of this fundraising campaign is to get our poets to the festival.

The team is the youngest in the history of the Canadian Festival of Spoken Word – all the poets on the team are 25 years of age and under, and four of them will compete in the festival for the first time. CFSW 2012 Saskatoon will be a career-changing opportunity for these poets. Your generous support will leave a lasting impact on the development of spoken word in the Region, and on the voices of these five amazing young poets. Your help in making this vision become a reality is greatly appreciated.

What We Need & What You Get

Funds from this campaign will be used to purchase round-trip tickets for the team from Toronto to Saskatoon, as well as cover the cost of a hotel stay for six days (October 8-14). The amount of our goal will fully cover the cost of the trip, but if we do not reach 100% or more of our target, the money we do raise will help defray the travel-related costs for the five university-aged youth on the team.

You get poetic gifts galore from the team depending on the level of contribution you provide – video poetry, chapbooks, a free poetry showcase, CDs and custom written poetry are all among the special goodies the YorkSlam team will give you as appreciation for your generous support.

The Impact

At a time when Markham is building a new city centre and a strong focus is being placed on developing the Region’s culture sector, YorkSlam provides an example of what is possible when people are energized and supported. We want to make sure our poets experience the best festival performance opportunities available to them in this country. Making sure the Team represents at CFSW 2012 Saskatoon will provide an additional push to the poetry series locally and boost the skill level of the poets who are representing us.

Once a poetry series sends a team to CFSW, the passion and fire of its poets is stoked to a new fever pitch. We believe strongly that YorkSlam can make a significant splash on the national level. First-year teams have previously found success and we are confident this Team will use your contributions to not just compete, but to contend as well. 

Other Ways You Can Help

We know you can’t always contribute financially, so spread the word as a way to help us as well! Share the link to this page with your friends, colleagues and contacts. Tell the media in the Region about what we’re doing. Use the Indiegogo share tools. Every little bit helps. Thanks for your support!!!

story:
Short Summary

Contributors fund ideas they can be passionate about and to people they trust. Here are some things to do in this section:

  • Introduce yourself and your background.
  • Briefly describe your campaign and why it’s important to you.
  • Express the magnitude of what contributors will help you achieve.

Remember, keep it concise, yet personal. Ask yourself: if someone stopped reading here would they be ready to make a contribution?

What We Need & What You Get

Break it down for folks in more detail:

  • Explain how much funding you need and where it’s going. Be transparent and specific—people need to trust you to want to fund you.
  • Tell people about your unique perks. Get them excited!
  • Describe where the funds go if you don’t reach your entire goal.

The Impact

Feel free to explain more about your campaign and let people know how the difference their contribution will make:

  • Explain why your project is valuable to the contributor and to the world.
  • Point out your successful track record with projects like this (if you have one).
  • Make it real for people and build trust.

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can’t contribute, but that doesn’t mean they can’t help:

  • Ask folks to get the word out and make some noise about your campaign.
  • Remind them to use the Indiegogo share tools!

And that’s all there is to it.

story:
Conversations|Reconstructed

5 April  - 19 April, 2014 

Opening evening reception 4 April - RSVP

The Culture Box, Temple Bar, Dublin, Ireland

The Concept

I've always been fascinated with the question: "What if?"  What if we did that another way? What if something we valued suddenly became something of no value or vice versa? What if the same words could tell a totally different story?

Several months ago, under the dark of night, a 'what if' conversation led to an idea...What if I could take apart stories and rebuild them to tell completely different ones? This led to an experiment...which repeated itself several times over...leading to countless conversations…which turned into bigger and bigger things…until it became...Conversations|Reconstructed.

For me, I have to pursue writing and art in the same way I pursue breathing. It must happen to stay alive. This project is the next breath in our pursuit of creating, pushing boundaries and collaboration. We have been awed by where it has already taken us, and we are eager to see where it will continue to lead us as artists and creators.

The Questions & The Details

What if I could take apart some of the greatest poems and use those words to reconstruct completely new stories? Could it be done? Could I do it? Would the words be able to tell different stories? Would I lose my voice if I could not choose my words, not a single one? Do words have enough meaning to tell different stories while they stay the same?

These are all the questions I asked myself as I began this journey. It was frustrating not to be able to choose my words but, as I started doing it, I saw the words, the same words, telling new and different stories.

Once I completed a couple reconstructions it became very apparent I needed visual artists to help bring my stories to life. As each artist joined the project, (Illustrator, Sculptor, Graphic Designer, Painter, Lino Cutter/Digital Printer, and Street Artist) a beautiful collaboration began between these artists, my reconstructions and the iconic poets. Not only were we able to bring the poem sets to life visually ("poem set" being the term we use to describe an original poem, de-constructed word list and reconstructed poem), but each artist involved used the words to inspire their own story.

You will recognize some of the greatest poets of all time in the works: Yeats, Kipling, Henley, Dickenson, Hughes, Frye, Brontë, Poe, Donne, & Frost.

As our team comes from various places in the world, you will also find an international flavour to our exhibition which brings an added dimension to these conversations. 

I worried about the constrained creativity this project entailed. I mean, come on, a writer who doesn't choose any of her own words?! I won't lie, it was a struggle, but I discovered even when you constrain creativity, creativity will not be constrained. Words carry meaning individually, and words together tell stories. You take them apart, put them back together and they can tell completely new stories. These stories then take on imagery, collaboration and multiple interpretations. Soon you find you are having new conversations out of the old ones!

Here's a sneak peek to aid your curiosity:

Unto One

One robin fainting in his nest.

Or one heart breaking again.

One life I live in vain.

If I shall stop,

Cool, the pain,

If I can live, can ease,

I shall help.

Not vain or not from aching 

unto one.

Reconstruction by Stacey Covell - (Original: 'If I Can Stop' by Emily Dickinson)

What We Need & What You Get

How You Can Help:

We need your help. Our goal is to raise €5000. By donating you are helping us reach our goal. Every cent you donate will go towards the costs and support of Conversations|Reconstructed and its artists. Your donations will provide funding for:

  • Promotional Materials, Début Exhibition Venue, Creation and Production of Art Book, Opening Reception, Hardware, Storing of Art, Shipping Costs, Support and Admin Costs. 

And...If we raise above our goal:

  • Artist's Shipping and Supply Costs, Compensation for Admin and Graphic Design Assistance, Travel Supplements for Artists who Live Far Away, and Possible Touring of Exhibition (possibilities include: Belgrade, Serbia; Chicago, USA; Belfast, UK).

Rewards For You:

By donating, you will, in turn, receive a reward (gift) directly connecting you to our project. These can include: 

  • Our Eternal Gratitude, Thank You Mention on my Personal Blog: One Beautiful Thing, Seeing Your Name In Print, Art Book, Postcard Print of Original Piece from the Show, Invitation to Our Opening Night, A Limited Edition Artwork of a Reconstructed Poem from the Exhibition Signed by Artist and Author. (Rewards are all listed to your right on this page.)

The Impact

Conversations|Reconstructed tells beautiful stories, both written and visually, on the power of words. The power they have to change and stay the same, to cross cultures, to exhibit great beauty, to affect all our senses.

You as the viewer will be taken on a journey. You will experience the power of words and story in multiple forms. Readers, writers and art lovers alike will enjoy wandering through these artworks and sharing in their conversations.

Your contributions will help these conversations be heard. You will help us showcase the great power words and artists have, to tell the same, and different, stories together.

Other Ways You Can Help

We realize that some of you just won't be able to contribute, but that doesn't mean you can’t still support us! 

So if you're excited about this conversation why not join in by sharing it through social media, face to face, word of mouth, anything to get the word out there and make some noise! Use the Indiegogo share buttons below to tell others about our fundraising campaign. If you're not all that in to social media, write a note, send an email, or simply tell a friend. Your support is one of the most valuable things we can have throughout this collaboration and hopefully, others to follow. For that, you have our deepest thanks! Thanks!!!

story:
VISION

All individuals have contributions to make - acts that nurture the individual and the community. Yet, people with limited use of their bodies, those considered to be physically or mentally disabled by some, often lack the resources, opportunities and relationships necessary to fully express themselves to make their contributions to society. Laser Eagles Art Guild is an organization that offers individuals the opportunity for self expression through art. The Laser Eagles will bring people together to passionately reveal their strong spirit and foster their ability to contribute their creativity and insight to the world.

The Laser Eagles Art Guild is one of the only art organizations in the Greater Toronto Area that provides fully-inclusive environments for those who have been labeled with a disability. The Laser Eagles artists gather weekly to create art that is generated solely from their own artistic visions. Laser Eagles’s trackers have formed wonderful nurturing relationships with Artists have produced a variety of artwork that are exceptional.

 

WWW.ARTENCOMPASSED.COM

Art Encompassed was developed to showcase, promote and sell art created by Toronto's artists, which includes Laser Eagles Art Guild, CAVE and supporting Community Artists. This state of the art online storefront facilitates the purchase of art produced in various forms including, originals, prints and greeting cards.

This site allows us to sell art to anywhere in North America allowing the Laser Eagles Art Guild and CAVE to become financially sustainable while continuing to make positive contributions to our communities.

 

MEET THE ARTISTS...

 

 

 

WHAT WE NEED

Here's where you come in. A large portion of the expenses for this project we hope will be funded through our fundraiser here on Indiegogo and the remainder through project donations.

Our goal is to raise $50,000

Friends We Turn To YOU!

Operating Expenses

$5,000   – Art Emcompassed Gallery

$9,000   – Part-time Program Manager

$12,000 – Part-time Program Coordinators

$5,000   – Program Administrator

$5,000   – Program Curator

$3,000   – Art Supplies

$7,000   – Trackers Stipend

$2,000   – Food and Special Events

$2,000   – Travel

 

YOUR IMPACT

Your donations will have a direct impact on creating a culture where everyone is respected as a contributor to his or her community and where everyone has the oportunity to access all community resources and supports. After 12 years of offering an invaluable services to individuals and the broader community we are excited to have the opportunity to expand our programs in three key areas: 

1) Creation of an online store that will promote economic stability for our Artists, Trackers, Art Coordinators and supporting Community Artists. Your generous donation will not only be supporting Laser Eagles programs but you will also be helping staff to create an entrepreneurial online community.

2) Expand and Engage with community partners and residents in new program ideas. Laser Eagles Art programs have a distinctive community service model approach. Laser Eagles Artists have a variety of abilities that they use in the creation of their art. Trackers partner with Artists in the facilitation of their work to fully utilize each artist’s unique abilities to create exceptional pieces of Art.

3) “ART MAKES THE WORLD GO ROUND” - Art transforms communities. Utilizing community centres, parks, public spaces and even sidewalks allows for greater accessibility where everyone has the privilege to enjoy the beauty of art. Your donation to The Laser Eagle Guild has a direct impact on arts and culture in the GTA and allows our Artists and Trackers to share their stories with others through the wonderful world of art.

 

   OTHER WAYS YOU CAN HELP

If you don’t have the money to contribute at this time, that’s okay, BUT we still need your help!

 Don’t be a stranger – Stop by and say HI!

www.lasereagles.com

Share the love - like us on our Facebook page and brag about us to ALL of your friends!

www.facebook.com/lasereagles

Spread the word - post our campaign on your LinkedIn account

Give us a "Shout Out" on Twitter

@lasereagles

 

CHECK OUT WHAT WE'VE BEEN UP TO LATELY...

 

Watch for a featured segment about The Laser Eagles Art Guild this fall on Accessibility in Action!

 13/13/13 Sketchbook Project

Global TV, Making a Difference

CDI College Spring Newsletter

Mississauga News

This state of the art online storefront facilitates the purchase of art produced in various forms including, originals, prints and greeting cards.
This site allows us to sell art to anywhere in North America allowing the Laser Eagles Art Guild and CAVE to become financially sustainable while continuing to make positive contributions to our communities.
  
MEET THE ARTISTS...
 
 
 
WHAT WE NEED
Here's where you come in. A large portion of the expenses for this project we hope will be funded through our fundraiser here on Indiegogo and the remainder through project donations.
Our goal is to raise $50,000


Friends We Turn To YOU!
Operating Expenses
$5,000   – Art Emcompassed Gallery
$9,000   – Part-time Program Manager 
$12,000 – Part-time Program Coordinators
$5,000   – Program Administrator
$5,000   – Program Curator 
$3,000   – Art Supplies
$7,000   – Trackers Stipend
$2,000   – Food and Special Events
$2,000   – Travel 
 
YOUR IMPACT
Your donations will have a direct impact on creating a culture where everyone is respected as a contributor to his or her community and where everyone has the oportunity to access all community resources and supports. After 12 years of offering an invaluable services to individuals and the broader community we are excited to have the opportunity to expand our programs in three key areas:  1) Creation of an online store that will promote economic stability for our Artists, Trackers, Art Coordinators and supporting Community Artists. Your generous donation will not only be supporting Laser Eagles programs but you will also be helping staff to create an entrepreneurial online community.
2) Expand and Engage with community partners and residents in new program ideas. Laser Eagles Art programs have a distinctive community service model approach. Laser Eagles Artists have a variety of abilities that they use in the creation of their art. Trackers partner with Artists in the facilitation of their work to fully utilize each artist’s unique abilities to create exceptional pieces of Art.
3) “ART MAKES THE WORLD GO ROUND” - Art transforms communities. Utilizing community centres, parks, public spaces and even sidewalks allows for greater accessibility where everyone has the privilege to enjoy the beauty of art. Your donation to The Laser Eagle Guild has a direct impact on arts and culture in the GTA and allows our Artists and Trackers to share their stories with others through the wonderful world of art.
 
   OTHER WAYS YOU CAN HELP
If you don’t have the money to contribute at this time, that’s okay, BUT we still need your help!
 Don’t be a stranger – Stop by and say HI!
www.lasereagles.com
Share the love - like us on our Facebook page and brag about us to ALL of your friends!
www.facebook.com/lasereagles
Spread the word - post our campaign on your LinkedIn account
Give us a "Shout Out" on Twitter
@lasereagles
 
CHECK OUT WHAT WE'VE BEEN UP TO LATELY... 
 
Watch for a featured segment about The Laser Eagles Art Guild this fall on Accessibility in Action!


 13/13/13 Sketchbook Project
Global TV, Making a Difference
CDI College Spring Newsletter


Mississauga News

story:
First of all thank you!

We have achieved our goal, thanks!

Do you want to help me a little bit now?

YOU are my patron, you get my Art, you support an emerging artist.

NOW I can buy supplies and I can work..but...if you want to be my patron...I will buy other materials for my Lab:oil colors, canvases, books and maybe I can dream another online course!

NOW OTHER 2 WEEKS OF CROWDFUNDING...IF YOU HELP ME I CAN SEND TO YOU A SPECIAL ART, A PERSONALIZED PAPER DOLL WITH YOUR FACE

 

 

I am Stefania Morgante and I am a figurative artist.

With your support now I am a student at MoMA online course about Abstract painting http://www.moma.org/learn/courses/online#course3.

 

THANK YOU!

but it's only the first step, now I need to buy art supplies, here the list:

•10”Light weight stretchers x 8
•14” Light weight stretchers x 20
•Unprimed, unstretched cotton duck
 • 1 quart white acrylic gesso
•About 10 standard house painter’s brushes, varie
ty of shapes and sizes,$
•Flat Size 40 brush
Palette knife
•Butcher’s tray
•8 oz Linseed Oil
•32 oz.Odorless Mineral Spirits
Oil Paints
Acrilyc paints media
acrylic paint
enamel paints
Various jars with lids, plastic yogurt containers, etc.
 Rags or paper towels
 Plastic drop cloth
 Masking tape
 Paint mixing sticks, turkey basters, etc. (for Pollock)
and a book (it's an optional, but recommends)
Ellen G. Landau. Reading Abstract Expressionism. Yale University Press. 2005.
ISBN-10: 0300106130; ISBN-13: 978-0300106138
 
 

with 550 euros I can buy art supplies an cover taxes costs and shipping costs for the supporters

I don't paint for years and so I need to buy brushes, canvas, mediums and so on but....The good News is that you will have pieces of art from me!

What You Get--ART ART ART by me!

 

These images  are only  examples, you can tell me what you want via email from my shop www.gufobardo.etsy.com

 

 
You send me your photo and I create your portrait on paper, with collage or not, mixed media or not, like this one.
It isn't fantastic to have an original portrait of YOU? watercolous, acrylics or pens with colors or black and white...
 
 
I promise: I will inform you step by step about the course, the project and what I am working.
 
Help an emerging artist to spread her art to the world!
ART changes the world and you are a part of it: with my art and your support we can change the world.
THANK YOU SO MUCH.
 
You can see my work here
www.stefaniamorgante.com
 
and you CAN SUPPORT ME buying on my shop (20% off coupon code LOVE9)
www.gufobardo.etsy.com

 

About ME

My name is Stefania Morgante, I am an italian artist.

I attended the Liceo Artistico (Italian secondary school specializing in Arts) in Lecce (South Italy), Architecture section.

I decided to follow a University I graduated in the Theory of Shapes at the DAMS of Bologna in 1992-section Visual Arts with Paolo Fabbri.

I wrote a graduation thesis on a Sylvia Plath’s poem, inspired by a De Chirico‘s painting The Disquieting Muses.

After a post-degree trip when I visited very dear friends, I offered my services as press office for the Cagliari theatre.

2002 I became a member of the Canadian Doll Artists Association (CDAA).

2005/2006 I exhibited the Ichnusa Bear which won the first prize in Novellara, Reggio Emilia, and the following year (2006) the Casanova Bear which also won the first prize.

2012 (July-August) Solo exhibition in Cagliari

2012 (October-November) Solo Exhibition in Nuoro

2012 December-2013 January collective exhibition

story:
Introduction:

Hi Family and Friends!

You will be happy to know that I am settled into the Windy City.  I have some exciting news from my studio, which is the foundation for this campaign titled: Studio Upkeep. In brief, Studio Upkeep is a project to raise money for the progression of my studio practice through the purchasing of my artworks.  I am excited to find homes for my works, which are ever growing and taking over many storage units across the country.  Thanks Dad, Uncle Mike, and the Muzzio’s.

Specifically, the monies will contribute to a residency at the Vermont Studio Center in Johnson, VT and the building of a website.  I have been invited for a month long residency where I will have the opportunity to be completely immersed in my studio.  The way the residency works is I am given a studio within a community of other dedicated resident painters, sculptors, and writers.  During my stay there will be visiting artist that come to give lectures on their work, in addition to, individual studio critiques.  Here is a link the artists that are coming the month of November:

http://www.vermontstudiocenter.org/november-5/

The good news is that I received a partial scholarship to attend!  However, the remaining tuition, travel, photographing of works, and material costs still remain.

The Way It Works:

Indiegogo is a free online platform where anyone can raise money for important causes or projects that they are passionate about.  If I reach my goal then Indiegogo keeps 4% of my earnings and if I don’t reach my goal Indiegogo keeps 9% of my earnings.  All of my earnings will go towards funding the building of a website that will better represent my paintings and a residency at the Vermont Studio Center this November 2013.

The Perks are the detail, which I am most excited about!  When you contribute toward my cause you will receive ART WORK!  See my Perks for more information!  Be sure to click on Shipping Fee depending on the size of your Perk. 

Be sure to check out the Gallery to view some of my works!


Other Studio News:

I was recently in a show titled Future Folk in Brooklyn, New York at Brooklyn Fireproof East. 

I have been selected for a catalogue that comes out a few times year called New American Paintings.  I am in the upcoming September Midwest Issue #107 you can order a catalogue here:

http://www.newamericanpaintings.com/

or contact me for a copy.

Other Ways You Can Help:

I completely understand not being able to support my campaign monetarily.  However, you can still support my campaign.  Make some noise and let you art collecting friends know about my project!

Use the ‘Share Tool’ at the bottom of my campaign description to share my project with others via email, social media, or your website.

story:
Who am I?

I’m Mrs. Kimberly Moseberry; I was born and raised here in Chicago. I’ve always had a passion for art and storytelling. When I was a kid I would read my brothers and uncles comic books. To mean comic books allowed me to go to new worlds and meet new people. In 2001 I attended the Illinois Institute of Art and got my BA in media arts and animation. People who know me always say that I enjoy doing art and writing stories. I’ve worked on a few indie projects such as AWF (Amazon Wrestling Federation) and Urban Style Comics.

Enigma is a project I had ever since I was a freshman in high school. Enigma allows me to create my own world and people where I can talk about mature issues and what it is to be human. In enigma there are no simple black and white characters only people trying to survive. Enigma is important to me because it’s a place things aren’t simple and even the best of people can do terrible things and the worst of people can do wonderful things.

Through you wonderful donations I can truly bring the world of enigma to life. With your help and donations you open up a whole new world where beauty isn’t always on the outside but on the inside.

What I need and what you get

To get Enigma off the ground running I’ll need $2600 total these donates will go to paying the colorist, lettering and the printing of the first issue of enigma as well as the concept art book which will allow you to look into the world of enigma itself as well as a quick peek at the characters who will be in the comic.

Now you’re asking well what are the perks what do you get? Good question. Depending on what you donate. You can get anywhere from the first issue of enigma to shirts, posters, buttons, prints, concept art book. If you have a comic book store and you want to make a donation. Your store gets free advertising in my comic book and my table no matter which convention I go to your stores ad will be there.

The Impact

With your donations Enigma will be colored, lettered and this printed. None of this would be possible without your help. Enigma isn’t as clear cut on black and white issues like good or evil. There is only the idea of surviving in a broken world as a human being. In a way Enigma makes us take a look at ourselves as people. Back in summer of 2012 at Wizard World Chicago. I sold 50 sneak peek copies of Enigma. As of right now Enigma has a small fan base of a few 100 followers. Enigma will grow in time.

Other Ways You Can Help

Now just because you are unable to make a donation, doesn’t mean you can contribute you can spread the world and tell other about Enigma. The more you know the more you can help! That’s it and thanks a lot folks!

story:
What:

Ovid’s Girls will be an exhibition at the Boston Sculptors Gallery featuring artworks by twelve female sculptors, six from the USA and six from Germany, all sharing an aesthetic of the evocative and enigmatic. The exhibition will highlight parallels and relationships in the artwork, in a cross-continent dialogue of ideas, materials, and conceptual approaches. 

Two companion exhibitions of Ovid's Girls, featuring the same artists, will be hosted at the Kunstverein Tiergarten in Berlin, Germany and at the MEWO Kunsthalle in Memmingen, Germany.


Why:

German curator, Anette Schwarz, conceived of Ovid’s Girls while visiting  Boston in 2010.  She was struck by the commonalities between sculpture she encountered in Boston and artwork being produced in Germany.  In the overlapping sensibilites and approaches, Schwarz saw compelling possibilities for exchange between German and American artists. 

The artists of Ovid’s Girls explore ways that a surface can both reveal and conceal.  Materials are not simply a vehicle, but provide meaning as well.  Often the artists turn to flexible, translucent, and unassuming media like wire, wax, cloth, paper, and rubber.  Surface, structure, and form reflect both a shared language as well as the unique touch of each artist. The exhibitions will be a conversation between form and material, between the familiar and the unexpected, as well as between artists.

This is a unique opportunity to bring high caliber contemporary German sculpture to the Boston art scene.  The exhibition will strengthen relations between the Boston/USA and Berlin/Germany art worlds.  Events, including an opening reception and talks by the curator and artists, will bring the public into this conversation. 

 

Who:

Curator - Anette Schwarz was born in 1963 in Wuppertal, Germany. She studied Art History as well as American and English Literature at the Philipps University of Marburg (MA 1991).  Since 1992 she has curated exhibitions in Berlin and Munich.

Boston/USA Artists – Rosalyn Driscoll, Laura Evans, Michelle Lougee, Julia Shepley, Hanah Verlin, Leslie Wilcox

Berlin/German Artists – Ulli Böhmelmann Alexandra Deutsch, Anke Eilergerhard, Flora Hitzing, Marina Schreiber, Frauke Wilken

  

Where & When:

The exhibition will be hosted by three different venues in 2014.  The first will be at the Kunstverein Tiergarten in Berlin, Germany (April 4 to May 3, 2014),  followed by the Boston Sculptors Gallery in Boston, USA (June 25 to August 3, 2014), and then at  the MEWO Kunsthalle in Memmingen, Germany (September 19 to November 8).

The German and Boston venues will present different sets of artworks by all 12 artists.  Viewers will see a cross-continental dialogue of ideas, materials, and conceptual approaches,  highlighting parallels and relationships in the artwork.   In addition, a catalogue will combine together the artworks from Boston and Germany.

Located in Boston’s SOWA neighborhood, Boston Sculptors Gallery is a landmark cooperative and has served as an alternative venue for exciting, innovative sculpture exhibitions since 1992.  It is Boston’s premier venue for sculpture, featuring exciting and varied contemporary work by Boston area artists.  Boston Sculptors is the only sculpture cooperative in the US to maintain a gallery.

The Elizabeth Firestone Graham Foundation has awarded a grant to produce a catalogue of both Boston and Berlin exhibitions.  This catalogue will be available in print and in digital form. 

Boston Sculptors Gallery is fiscally sponsored by the Arts and Business Council of Greater Boston, Inc., a 501(c)(3) non-profit tax-exempt organization.  All contributions are fully deductible to the extent allowed by law.


How:

With your help! 

Sculpture is a tricky business.  It it time consuming to make, difficult to install, and costly to transport.  Putting on an international exhibition amplifies all of these costs.  Your support will help us to defray some of these expenses.  Again, all contributions are tax deductible.


What this funding WILL cover:

  - Shipping artwork to and from Germany

  - Promotion materials/advertising

  - Gallery expenses

 

What this funding WONT cover:

  - Travel expenses for the artists

  - Installation expenses

  - Creation of artwork

Even if you cannot contribute please spread the word, come to the exhibition, and attend the public events listed at www.bostonsculptors.com. We would love to see you there!

story:
Send Satellite66 to ArtPadSF!

In less than a year, Satellite66 has exhibited 24 artists in 7 exhibitions. We've hosted workshops, book readings, and pop-ups. We've received media attention and glowing reviews. And we've done all this from one of the most challenging blocks in the city of San Francisco, and on a shoe-string budget.

What We Need & What You Get

Art fairs are amazing networking opportinities for galleries. We will meet thousands of potential new clients in a matter of days, and meet dozens of our fellow gallerists from all over. We MUST to go to ArtPadSF, but exhibitor fees are sizable. ArtPad is one of the more accessible art fairs, with some booths just below $5K...  We can cover MOST of that, but we need a little help making up the difference!

We need about $1,750 to go to ArtPad... but MORE is BETTER! Everything we raise will go towards exhibitor fees... and $1,750 is just a fraction of that.

When you donate to our cause, get your money back through Art!  Take whatever amount you donate off of any art purchase at Satellite66, anytime, ever (up to 50% off of purchase price).  You can use that at the fair or at the gallery. So you're not just helping us out, you're also paying for your future art!

Donate $300 or more and we throw a cocktail party for you and your friends in your honor.

Want to donate an amount not listed here?  Have an idea for a different reward?  Just contact me and let me know, I'll add your amount and your reward. valerie@satellite66.org

What We Get!

We participate in the hippest fair in SF, at the Phoenix Hotel in the Tenderloin, May 17-20.  We get to bring our artists to the fair and increase their exposure and hopefully help them sell their work!  We increase the gallery profile in the community, and hopefully meet a bunch of new clients that will help us maintain our presence in the challenging but blossoming Central Market corridor for a long time.

Other Ways You Can Help

Get the word out and make some noise about our campaign!

Email your friends, post it on Facebook, Tweet about it, use the IndieGoGo share tools!  Now get going and send us to ArtPadSF!
story_txt:
Send Satellite66 to ArtPadSF!
In less than a year, Satellite66 has exhibited 24 artists in 7 exhibitions. We've hosted workshops, book readings, and pop-ups. We've received media attention and glowing reviews. And we've done all this from one of the most challenging blocks in the city of San Francisco, and on a shoe-string budget.


What We Need & What You Get
Art fairs are amazing networking opportinities for galleries. We will meet thousands of potential new clients in a matter of days, and meet dozens of our fellow gallerists from all over. We MUST to go to ArtPadSF, but exhibitor fees are sizable. ArtPad is one of the more accessible art fairs, with some booths just below $5K...  We can cover MOST of that, but we need a little help making up the difference!
We need about $1,750 to go to ArtPad... but MORE is BETTER! Everything we raise will go towards exhibitor fees... and $1,750 is just a fraction of that.
When you donate to our cause, get your money back through Art!  Take whatever amount you donate off of any art purchase at Satellite66, anytime, ever (up to 50% off of purchase price).  You can use that at the fair or at the gallery. So you're not just helping us out, you're also paying for your future art!
Donate $300 or more and we throw a cocktail party for you and your friends in your honor.
Want to donate an amount not listed here?  Have an idea for a different reward?  Just contact me and let me know, I'll add your amount and your reward. valerie@satellite66.org


What We Get!
We participate in the hippest fair in SF, at the Phoenix Hotel in the Tenderloin, May 17-20.  We get to bring our artists to the fair and increase their exposure and hopefully help them sell their work!  We increase the gallery profile in the community, and hopefully meet a bunch of new clients that will help us maintain our presence in the challenging but blossoming Central Market corridor for a long time.


Other Ways You Can Help
Get the word out and make some noise about our campaign!
Email your friends, post it on Facebook, Tweet about it, use the IndieGoGo share tools!  Now get going and send us to ArtPadSF!

story:
Our Story

Hiya, my names Vicky Blackthorn. I was at university studying marine science and now I'm training with the circus and teaching at a circus school. Since starting at circus I've found my home and my family, and I've always had dreams to combine my two passions, aerials and the ocean. I've been invited to be a part of a trapeze beach camp in Byron Bay in which I'll be able to fly on the trapeze over the ocean and learn a new way of connecting to the aerials to pass onto the children back home. This is possibly the most amazing opportunity I could hope for. I feel a deeply spiritual connection with the ocean and with the trapeze, and feel that I can create something truely amazing through this project to give to the children at my circus school. 

The Impact

I am passionate about children, their vibrancy, spontaneity and fearlessness. At circus I teach children to live their dreams and to do things they never thought possible. I believe that in attending this trapeze camp I will come back to my circus school with even more passion and new skills to pass on to my students, to get them closer to their dreams of flying.

 

What I Need

To attend the trapeze beach camp I need to raise $1500, this covers airfares as well as the cost of the camp itself. If I don't raise the full $1500 through this campaign then I will be selling off my furniture in order to attend the camo. So, please be generous, or I won't have a bed to sleep on in the forseeable future

Other Ways You Can Help

Please get the word out and make some noise about my campaign, tell your friends and family and anyone who might be interested. And remember the share tools, to show everyone!

 

Thanks so much everyone!

 

Vicky :)

story:
Introducing Out Loud Greetings

Out Loud Greetings was started to make adorable greeting cards for the LGBT community.



CURRENTLY, I'm raising funds to cover printing costs, acquire supplies, and exhibit in the 2014 National Stationery Show so that Out Loud Greetings can be seen by thousands of potential reps and buyers from across the country.

Greeting cards can be one of the fondest, most sincere ways to show someone their special place in your heart. With images and words alone, greeting cards have the potential to inspire, heal, celebrate, and so much more. Out Loud Greetings is a business who’s mission it is to bring that sentiment and meaning, through greeting cards, to the gay and lesbian community.

FINALLY, Cards that celebrate holidays, weddings, anniversaries, and other special occasions with images that are modest, thoughtful, and heartfelt.


*Pictured above is a sample of a booth at the National Stationery Show

WHERE DOES THE MONEY GO?

So far the online customers and local shops have been fantastic. To take the cards and the message to the next level and play with the big guys, there's no other place to do it other than right here in NYC at the National Stationery show next spring. The multi-day event is visited by thousands of reps and store owners - hopefully propelling Out Loud Greetings into the hands and hearts of people across the country.



So MANY thanks in advance for your support!
