story:
Cascadia! Stickers for Everyone Campaign

For everyone who loves the idea of Cascadia, and would like a stack of stickers for friends, families, and to plaster on everything and everywhere, we're starting a brand new Cascadia Stickers for Everyone campaign:

The idea is simple

  • As many 3x5" Cascadia Flag Stickers as you can buy (they come in bundles of 250)
  • At cost (.10c a piece or less)
  • Stickers are Vinyl, just the flag (no markings or promo stuffs).
  • Great opportunity for individuals, groups, businesses, projects and events. Stock up, give them out.
  • Shipping is included in the price.

After that, you're welcome to use them for whatever you like. Give them to friends, use them as promotional items, sell them to raise money for your cause, get up around the community and into local cafes and bookstores - the choice your is yours!

With this campaign, our goal is to get 10,000-50,000 Cascadia stickers directly out into the community, for everyone who wants them. 

Why Cascadia Stickers?

The idea was spawned because here at CascadiaNow! we originally had several thousand. We've been giving them out - at events, in person, and with every order or letter we send out. We've finally run out, and rather than just re-order, we realized it might be a wonderful opportunity to let anyone who would like to get in on the order. 

In addition, what a great way to get them out there! With their order, we hope that each person will help us become an agent of change, helping to raise awareness and make the idea visible.

What does the Doug Flag stand for?

The Cascadia Doug flag is a symbol for the natural beauty and inspiration that the Pacific Northwest provides, and is a direct representation of the bioregion.

Designed in 1994 by Portland native Alexander Baretich, the blue of the flag represents the moisture-rich sky above, and the Pacific Ocean, along with the Salish Sea, lakes, and inland waters. Our home is a place of continuous cascading waters flowing from the Pacific to the western slopes of the Rockies and Cascades where water cycles back to the Pacific. The white represents snow and clouds, and the green represents the evergreen forests and fields of the Pacific Northwest. The lone-standing Douglas Fir symbolizes endurance, defiance, and resilience. All these symbols come together to symbolize what being Cascadian is all about.

While the Doug flag is the most common symbol for Cascadia, it is one of many, each representing watersheds or unique aspects of the Pacific Northwest.

Not one flag, but thousands!

story:
About me and The June Singers:

My name is Andy McMillan and I’m a fine art and editorial photographer based in Charlotte, NC. Over the past eight years, I’ve been able to work with some incredible publications and art institutions including Time, The New York Times Magazine, Mother Jones and the Corcoran Gallery of Art. However, this Summer I’m presented with the unique opportunity to do something that will be a first for me; spend a substantial, concentrated amount of time focused solely on the act of making art.

From April 14th – August 19th I’ll be an Affiliate Artist at the McColl Center for Visual Art in Charlotte, NC. The McColl offers one of the top residence programs in the country providing artists with logistical support to take their practice to the next level while establishing meaningful connections within the greater Charlotte community.

While at the McColl, I’ll be working on a series of photographs titled The June Singers that takes a look at how men relate to visual space. Drawing influence from various sources including Civil War photographs and Carson MacCullers’ The Heart Is A Lonely Hunter, I aim to create a complex portrait of contemporary male experience. The portraits are made using a 4x5 in film camera, which allows me to make extremely detailed, large-format prints. In addition to showing  at the McColl Center, I will use this new body of work to begin pursuing shows in New York galleries and applying to grad school. 

John and his adopted son, Ray from The June Singers.


Funding Goal:

Today, photographic images are produced and disseminated at a pace that almost seems to surpass our ability to acknowledge their existence. However, in my practice I've begun to slow down. I'm photographing The June Singers with a view camera that uses 4x5 inch sheet film. The process is cumbersome and expensive but in the Instagram era, seems necessary for making compelling images worthy of extended thoughtful looking. 

I aim to raise $4,000.00 from this campaign. This will cover the lion's share of the cost of producing this body of work, from purchasing film to framing the large-format prints. 

Here's a breakdown of where the money will go:

Film (color, bw) - $650.00

Processing - $700.00

Scanning/printing - $1,000.00

Studio fees - $875.00

Framing - $775.00

Total - $4,000.00


Your help:

I hope that you'll consider purchasing a print and contributing toward the completion of The June Singers. I'm so excited about this new body of work. But like so many artists before me, I'm dependent on the generous support of my community. 

If you're unable to purchase a print, please consider sharing a link to my project with your friends and family using indigogo's share tools. 

I look forward to sharing the completed new work with you this Summer! And I hope to see many of you at some point around the McColl.


About the perks:

To view the six images of which prints are being offered, click the gallery tab at the top right. All prints are from the series PTL. To learn more about this series see my website:  http://andymcmillanphoto.com/ptl/ 

Thanks so much!
story_txt:
About me and The June Singers:
My
name is Andy McMillan and I’m a fine art and editorial photographer based in
Charlotte, NC. Over the past eight years, I’ve been able to work with some
incredible publications and art institutions including Time, The New York Times
Magazine, Mother Jones and the Corcoran Gallery of Art. However, this Summer
I’m presented with the unique opportunity to do something that will be a first
for me; spend a substantial, concentrated amount of time focused solely on the act of making art. 
From
April 14th – August 19th I’ll be an Affiliate Artist at the McColl
Center for Visual Art in Charlotte, NC. The McColl offers one of the top
residence programs in the country providing artists with logistical support to
take their practice to the next level while establishing meaningful connections
within the greater Charlotte community.

While at the McColl, I’ll be working on a series
of photographs titled The June Singers that takes a look at how men relate to
visual space. Drawing influence from various sources including Civil War
photographs and Carson MacCullers’ The Heart
Is A Lonely Hunter, I aim to create
a complex portrait of contemporary male experience. The portraits are made using a 4x5 in film camera, which allows me to make extremely detailed, large-format prints. In addition to showing  at the McColl Center, I will use this new body of work to begin pursuing shows in New York galleries and applying to grad school. John and his adopted son, Ray from The June Singers.Funding Goal:Today, photographic images are produced and disseminated at a pace that almost seems to surpass our ability to acknowledge their existence. However, in my practice I've begun to slow down. I'm photographing The June Singers with a view camera that uses 4x5 inch sheet film. The process is cumbersome and expensive but in the Instagram era, seems necessary for making compelling images worthy of extended thoughtful looking. I aim to raise $4,000.00 from this campaign. This will cover the lion's share of the cost of producing this body of work, from purchasing film to framing the large-format prints. Here's a breakdown of where the money will go:Film
(color, bw) - $650.00Processing - $700.00Scanning/printing - $1,000.00Studio fees - $875.00Framing - $775.00Total - $4,000.00Your help:I hope that you'll consider purchasing a print and contributing toward the completion of The June Singers. I'm so excited about this new body of work. But like so many artists before me, I'm dependent on the generous support of my community. If you're unable to purchase a print, please consider sharing a link to my project with your friends and family using indigogo's share tools. I look forward to sharing the completed new work with you this Summer! And I hope to see many of you at some point around the McColl.About the perks:To view the six images of which prints are being offered, click the gallery tab at the top right. All prints are from the series PTL. To learn more about this series see my website:  http://andymcmillanphoto.com/ptl/ Thanks so much!

story:
Urban Allure




Urban Allure is an artist collective based in Los Angeles California. Urban Allure is composed of singers, song writers, dancers, musicians, poets, rappers, photographers, and videographers, all under the age of 25. Urban Allure writes, produces, and showcases all of our content, guaranteeing everything you hear and see is original!  This Campaign is SO important to us because we want our voices to be heard. We  want to be able to reach a wider audience with our music, and our live multi-media productions. Contributing to our campaign would help tremendously.


Our Project is Valuable not only to us but also for the arts and those who enjoy art. Our mission is to create a space for those listening to be enlightened while being inspired. Our message is for the young and the old we express what is real for us and often times it is what is really for others.  We want to challenge each other, while also challenging our audience to identify their role in their communities to help change it. Our collective was constructed with the intention of making honest art through multi-media by constructively honing in on the things that happen in everyones lives. 


What We Need

We need to raise $10,000!

Your contribution to Urban Allure will be helping fund the essential things we need to continue running productions and to begin recording our songs. Things can become very costly between production cost along with recording and equipment cost. These are the fundamental things you will be helping us acquire for up coming shows.

We do live performances, therefore we need live instruments such as:

Stage Piano, Guitar, Drum sets, Mics and Amps

Funds will also be going to Production Cost, Studio Cost, Rehearsal Space, Recording equipment, Printing Cost along with Distributing and Marketing. 

If we don't reach our entire goal the funds will continue to go to the essential tools that we need to help us grow. 


Thank you!!



Quotes from our Last Show:

"...What's so attracting about Urban Allure is that they are all already unique individually, by themselves, but they do such a good job performing together & mixing each member's sound, voice, look & energy into one kick ass vibe. Because of their variety, they attract different types of people - younger listeners AND older listeners and many different races/cultures etc., That benefits them greatly (they packed the house). The content of their lyrics alone showed how consciously aware they all are. The poets spoke their real words with so much conviction. The singers sang their hearts out in smooth, sultry voices w/ chromatic harmonies to compliment the song. And the musicians played with groove. The love of their gifts & music itself was easily seen in their connection & passion on stage..." - Flow Culture Blog


“The Urban Allure show has been by far one of the best events I've attended, the energy was amazing between the group it was great to see them supporting one another and the connection I felt with them just being in the crowd. I enjoyed how personal each artists piece was and the singers where absolutely amazing, it gave me chills. Above all it was well organized the flow was on point and the location was perfect. I can't wait until the next show to show my support.”-Elisia Morales, Musician.

“Urban Allure is the ILLEST! These talented young people bring an amazing example of art-meets-hustle-meets-beauty. I've seen them perform three times now, and every time, I have goose bumps. The lyrics are all powerful. The energy is consuming. There's no way you could just sit through a UA show and not be gushing with excitement. I see great things for this group. All the way, yo!!”  -Joseline, Artist.


“This collective of wildly talented, raw, and natural artists transcend and supersede the idea of an awe feeling moment with the idea of an awe feeling experience. Urban Allure tackles stereotypes and stigmas planted in the soil of an urban generation branded with an X. They communicate the concept that through the power of art and expression one can see the brilliance made, manifest in all of God's creations regardless of race, sex, orientation, age, or class. I left the experience/show, feeling inspired, touched, passionate, eager, and healed. They are the voice of our generation, and it is beyond necessary for them to be heard across galaxies.” -Nathaniel Lovell, Student.

story: I'm Savannah, a student at UW Madison. I'm kinda smart, but not really, since I let myself get concussed. I stopped being able to work (I have a job peddling games at GameStop), but conveniently, I have way too many unused art supplies. SO. If you give me $5 so I can pay rent, I will give you a portrait. Your face. A loved one's face. To prove that I can do art, I will post some. Not today. But tomorrow, maybe. Anyway. I'd like to make rent for December, and it's $452. Please help me, I'm small.

story:
My name is Maria Madeira. I am East Timorese. I am an Artist. I have recently been invited by the Jakarta Arts Council to present a solo fine art exhibition at the prestigious Galeri Cipta II, within the Jakarta Arts Centre complex. Please see the invitation letter below:

I am honoured and extremely proud to have been given this opportunity.

My exhibition is titled "Ina Lou” (Dear Mother Earth), and will take place between the 1st to the 15th of September 2014. It will show my latest artwork, expressing the notion of revival and renaissance of the feminine aspect of our cultural identity, especially from a contemporary female perspective. It will be an attempt in celebrating the cultural rebirth of our motherland, which is overflowing with the fingerprints of our fore-mothers.

This is the first time an East Timorese female artist, has been invited to a leading arts gallery in the Indonesian capital. This is a reconciliation opportunity to help me further appreciate the distinctive and diverse cultural identities of these two nations with a turbulent past.

The gallery will provide the venue and curator for the exhibition, but  I have to cover all the cost involved with the event. I have so far received confirmation of support from the President's office, the Secretariat of State for Arts & Culture here in Timor-Leste, and small donations from some close friends and family. But the money raised so far does not cover my budget. So, I am crowdfunding the rest here in Indiegogo, so that I can successfully carry out this exhibition. Please check my budget below:

EXHIBITION BUDGET (US$)                                                                        

Personal assistant, translator and interpreter         $1,000
Airfares and travel insurance                                         $1,850                                                     Shipping and transportation of artworks                   $950
Stretching and framing of artworks                             $1,250
Accommodation                                                                 $2450
Food                                                                                        $1,750
Transport within Jakarta                                                  $1000
Catalogue graphic design                                                $2000
Catalogue printing                                                              $5,000
Invitation, postcards, prints and advertising            $2,500
Catering for the opening                                                  $3,000
Rewards packing & posting from Jakarta                  $2,500
Crowdfunding site fees & taxes                                     $2,500
TOTAL                                                                                     $27,750
Funds raised to date                                                          $4,400
TOTAL TO RAISE                                                       $23,350

Most of my new paintings are produced entirely with raw and natural materials found around the country such as betel-nut spittle, red earth, ground stones and riverbed ochres, human hair, coffee powder and 'tais', traditional E. Timorese cloth. This is to emphasise my belief and trust on the boundless natural resources giving to us by our ‘dear mother earth’ and, to highlight my deep connection to my motherland, understanding and exploring our rich traditional cultural background and trying to rejuvenate, and celebrate it with other societies.

Throughout my professional life, I have successfully accomplished over twenty solo or group exhibitions of my paintings, sculptures, drawings, mixed media collages and installation pieces, across Australia, Portugal, Brazil, Macau and Timor-Leste.

I hold a B.A. Fine Arts (Visual Arts) Degree from Curtin University in 1991, a Graduate Diploma of Education (Major in Art) from Curtin University in 1993, and a B.A. in Political Science from Murdoch University in 1996. I am currently completing a Doctor of Philosophy - Art at Curtin University, Australia.

If you ever wanted to support Timor-Leste's artists, this is your chance. MAKE THIS EXHIBITION HAPPEN. You can help me from as little as $5. Please hurry, I only have 15 days to put this together.

My deepest gratitude.

Maria Madeira

story:
Hi. I'm Marlaena.  I'm an artist and a writer.  I've been an artist and a writer since always, but this is the first time I've illustrated and written a book. My plan is to write and illustrate books for the rest of always, but I really need your help this first time.  

I know my books will do well.  I just don't want to wait for a publisher.  One will find me.  I know that my future holds good and exciting things, and I have so many stories to tell you, each one better than the last.  So I'm going to  stop waiting around and get it all started right now.  

Even if you start out fighting like cats and dogs, the simplest act of kindness can start a friendship that lasts a lifetime.  That's what my first book is about.

If you help me to be able to tell the story, you won't just be donating money.  You'll receive copies of the book, and prints of the original book artwork by September 30 of this year.  You'll also be helping me to begin a career.

Here's a little breakdown:

Digital imaging of the book artwork costs $1,800.  The first printing will cost around $6,000.  There are marketing costs, and costs for shipping.  Those are variable.  I can come up with a portion of the money, but not nearly all of it, so I've asked for what I don't have.  

As soon as there is enough money, the artwork will be imaged here in Clearwater, FL.  Then, the digital files will be sent through space by magic to Centralia, WA, where the book will be designed by Joli Winsett, the most gifted graphic artist in all the land.  After that, the book will be printed by Gorham Printing. Upon completion of printing, I will squeal gleefully, do a happy dance,  and begin shipping books and artwork to everyone who has helped me here.

If you can't contribute money, that doesn't mean you have no way to help.  Share this on Facebook.  Tell your friends.  I really would appreciate it.  

Thank you for anything you do to help this story to have a happy ending.

Marlaena.

story:
About CFSW / Qu'est ce que FCSW?

The Canadian Festival of Spoken Word began as a small festival in Ottawa in 2004. At that time, it was dubbed the Canadian Spoken Wordlympics. The first festival included six teams of poets and a small number of guests in attendance. In just nine short years, the festival has grown from six teams to over twenty, with over 2,500 guests in attendance.  This year will be the 10th annual CFSW and the first time it will be hosted in Montreal between Nov 4-9, 2013.

This year, the festival organizing committee is excited to launch a brand new initiative within the world of CFSW. With our diverse language initiative, CFSW 2013 will become the first officially bilingual nationwide spoken word festival. 

With that in mind, the festival includes a wide diversity of events such as:

Performance, marketing and touring workshops, Youth showcases to promote literacy in younger generations, Elders showcases to honour and recognize our more established poets, Indigenous voices showcases, Bilingualism in spoken word across Canada and poetic translation, Panel discussions on topics ranging from youth outreach and queer education to ethics and creating safe-space in communities. 

Le Festival canadien de Spoken Word a commencé par un petit événement à Ottawa en 2004. À cette époque, on l’appelait le Canadian Spoken Worldympics, et six équipes de poètes y participaient devant un petit groupe d’invités. En seulement neuf ans, le festival a beaucoup grandi; il compte maintenant plus que vingt équipes.

Cette année, le comité d’organisation du festival est fier de lancer une nouvelle initiative dans le monde du FCSW. Avec l’initiative « Diverse Language/Diversité des langues », le FCSW deviendra le premier festival de slam officiellement bilingue au Canada.

Le but principal du festival est de favoriser la croissance de la communauté de slam au Canada. C’est pourquoi le festival vous offre des événements aussi diversifiés. En voici des exemples :

Ateliers de performance, de publicité et de tournées, Spectacles de la jeunesse pour encourager la scolarisation des jeunes, Spectacles des anciens pour honorer et reconnaître nos poètes plus établis, Spectacles des voix des Premières nations, Bilinguisme dans la communauté slam (spoken word) au Canada et traduction de poésie. Débats d’experts sur des sujets comme la diffusion pour la jeunesse, la sensibilisation sur à l’homosexualité, l’éthique et la création d’espaces sécuritaires dans les communautés.

Specific Highlight Events include:

Friday November 8th @ Sala Rossa (daytime): Youth roots day bringing youth from over 10 schools and communities together to perform, learn and dialogues between teaching poets.

Saturday November 9th @ Montreal, arts interculturels (daytime): Indigenous + endangered languages panel and workshops.

Saturday November 9th @ Montreal, arts interculturels (daytime): Insta-translation performance featuring Sheri-D Wilson, Fabrice Koffy with translation by Eliz Robert as well as translation panel (co-presented by LTAC/ATTLAC)

Saturday November 9th @ theatre Rialto (evening): "Mystics & Muses" closing night with feature performances by our poets of honour: Tanya Evanson & José Acquelin, as well as special opening performance by Atikamekh storyteller Jacques Newashish.

Nov 5 - 7: Cinq à sept feature showcases highlighting local and national talents, as well as Soirées Spectaculaires - Late Night Shows at 11pm.

Friday November 8th @ Cabaret du Mile End (evening): Semi-Finals late-night "Soundclash" showcase featuring members of Nomadic Massive & Kalmunity Vibe Collective.

What we need:

Up to this point, the festival has been funded with support from the Canada Council for Arts, as well as numerous volunteer hours from a dedicated group of volunteers.  There are however still costs to cover to put on a festival of this size.

These include but are not limited to:
- Paying artists to put on workshops for the community
- Sound and Projection costs
- Bringing in artists from isolated communities
- Graphic design and printing costs
- Accommodation for featured artists

Check back for more perks!  Check often for perks.  Also, visit us on the web at www.cfsw.ca


Spread the word, spread the love!

If you can't contribute financially, you can always help share the word with friends by using the share buttons here, sending an email, picking up the phone, sharing the video link and spreading the word about the festival!

Thank you for your time and love!

November 8th @ Sala Rossa (daytime): Youth roots day bringing youth from
over 10 schools and communities together to perform, learn and dialogues
between teaching poets.
Saturday
November 9th @ Montreal, arts interculturels (daytime): Indigenous +
endangered languages panel and workshops.
Saturday
November 9th @ Montreal, arts interculturels (daytime): Insta-translation
performance featuring Sheri-D Wilson, Fabrice Koffy with translation by Eliz
Robert as well as translation panel (co-presented by LTAC/ATTLAC)
Saturday
November 9th @ theatre Rialto (evening): "Mystics & Muses"
closing night with feature performances by our poets of honour: Tanya Evanson
& José Acquelin, as well as special opening performance by Atikamekh
storyteller Jacques Newashish.
Nov 5 - 7:
Cinq à sept feature showcases highlighting local and national talents, as well
as Soirées Spectaculaires - Late Night Shows at 11pm.
Friday
November 8th @ Cabaret du Mile End (evening): Semi-Finals late-night
"Soundclash" showcase featuring members of Nomadic Massive &
Kalmunity Vibe Collective.
 What we need: 
Up to this
point, the festival has been funded with support from the Canada Council for
Arts, as well as numerous volunteer hours from a dedicated group of
volunteers.  There are however still costs to cover to put on a festival
of this size. 
These include but are not limited to: 
- Paying artists to put on workshops for the community
- Sound and Projection costs
- Bringing in artists from isolated communities 
- Graphic design and printing costs
- Accommodation for featured artists
Check back for more perks!  Check often for perks.  Also, visit us on the web at www.cfsw.ca

 Spread the word, spread the love! 
If you can't contribute financially,
you can always help share the word with friends by using the share buttons
here, sending an email, picking up the phone, sharing the video link and
spreading the word about the festival! 
Thank you for your time and love!

story:
Helping an indie-bookshop owner step into the future by taking a step into the past...

Hello, my name is Alex Green.  I own a small, independent bookstore just outside of Boston.  For over five years, I've published authors the oldest way it can be done, using letterpress machines and lead letter type.  I've worked with Pulitzer Prize winners and even a Nobel Laureate, using this five hundred year old art to create beautiful prints of their works, but the catch is, I don't have my own equipment.  I could use your support to change that fact, purchase a press, and even open up to the public for classes!

Printing, circa 1500

To print my work, I ride buses with lead trays in my hands.  I carry cases of lead letters on trains.  It's romantic, but it's also a bit absurd.  For each piece, ink colors are mixed, paper is carefully selected, images are carved in blocks, and every letter (thousands of them ... even the spaces) cast in lead, is patiently set by hand.  It's a slow process.  Sometimes a single page takes 100 hours to design and print, but by slowing the world down, the result is an art that can't be done any other way.

A Weighty Dream ~ The Rewards

Letterpress equipment is heavy machinery and much of it isn’t made anymore.  To purchase a press, trays of type, and all of the things you need for tinkering with old machines will cost around $17,500, with much of the cost going toward purchasing and moving a press into a good location.  Fonts of type will be purchased, and sometimes cast by foundries in New York and California.  In return for supporting this project, I'm offering the works on which I'm currently working or completing, including:

Haiku Cards and Prints

Ellis Avery is the bestselling author of two major novels, and she writes a haiku a day.  These aren't your average run-of-the-mill hokey haiku.  They send a beautiful message.  For that reason, I've set five of them as greeting cards on heavy card stock, like this one:


And I'm at work setting one as a print on Japanese mulberry paper, to greet a guest who comes to your front door.  The haiku reads:

Old pier.  Late sun gilds the gray wood gold.  You are still not tired of beauty.

WAL-LEX Bowling Alley Poster

Where a printer lives makes an impression on all they do.  I often work with serious projects, but this 1950s poster from Waltham's famous Wal-Lex Bowling Alley is something special:

Pablo Neruda's "Ode to Walt Whitman"

167 lines.  Neruda's great ode to America's great poet, translated and signed by Ilan Stavans.  This massive print took three months to design and print.  The ink is a two-tone hand-mixed concoction with graphite dust and a blind embossed Spanish accent on the bottom left corner.

"To Paula in Late Spring" ~ Poet Laureate W.S. Merwin

A hyper-limited print of "To Paula in Late Spring" by former Poet Laureate and two-time Pulitzer Prize recipient W.S. Merwin.  Set in Walbaum type, printed on Thai paper.

Just for You

If you are able to support this project at a significant level, I'll print something just for you and our first published book will bear your name as benefactor.  Here's a little book I published last year:

"Triptych" ~ Nobel Laureate Seamus Heaney, Signed

A signed letterpress broadside of Seamus Heaney's last published poem.  One of only 26 printed and signed by the Nobel Laureate.  Only one remains, for the person able to contribute at the highest level.

Impact, Risks, and Goals

Your support helps an old-school dream become a reality.  Anything you can do to support this goal is something for which I'm profoundly grateful.  As I've learned by being a bookseller, just spreading the word alone is a huge support.  If you can do even more, I'm honored for your help.

If for any reason this project does not reach its goals, it's still a step closer to reality than before, and any promise made in the gifts section will be seen to conclusion.  You'll get my gift of gratitude come hell or high water.

There is always the potential for delay, whether in shipments of paper or supplies, but I'm nearly 100% certain that the goals set here are achievable.  If we exceed them, I'll look toward opening up my press for classes!

story:
Passion for Paper

Organic and geometric, elaborate and contemporary, decorative and functional. These unique lanterns are the imaginative works of paper artist and designer Roy Hoggard. The results are nothing short of stunning. They are art, illuminated.

 

The Paper Lanterns

Twisted, Arabesque, and Sputnik. Three paper lanterns are available. They each have their own unique geometric shape and pattern for your enjoyment. They are constructed out of high quality thick coated paper that is recycled and are backed with thick vellum paper that allows the light shine through revealing the beautiful designs.

 

Twisted

Dimensions: 26 in. x 11 in. x 11 in.

 

 

Arabesque

Dimensions: 13.5 in. x 18 in. 18 in.

 

 

Sputnik

Dimensions: 24 in. x 24 in. x 24 in.

 

 

LED Lighting and Cord

The lanterns come with a 15 ft. UL approved cord and LED light. There are two options available for lighting, both are energy efficient 60 watt equivalent LEDs. One is a White LED, the other is a Multi-Color LED with a remote control. 

                                                                              

 

Sixteen different colors are possible with the Multi-Color LED as well as multiple lighting effects.                                                                                                                     

 

Pre-order the paper lanterns now, support a great cause and receive below retail pricing!

The lanterns come pre-assembled and are ready to hang right out of the box!

 

Who We Are

Roy Hoggard, LLC is a Stockton, CA design company, focused on creating the imaginative works of artist and designer Roy Hoggard.

                  

 History

Since he was a young boy, Roy has viewed paper differently than most people. He sees possibilities of complex objects within simple paper that many others do not, similar to gazing upon a cloud, one person may see a deer while another sees a rabbit, or they may simply just see a cloud. His passion for paper awakened when he was just seven years old when he began experimenting with paper as a favored art medium; he's been creating with it and honing his craft ever since.

Roy's interest in strong geometric shapes and patterns, his eye for graphic flair and intricate paper work has taken him across the globe. His work has been featured in cities throughout the California Central Valley, San Francisco, New York City, and Japan. Some of the artist's more notable achievements have been being commissioned to make decorative paper boxes for Tiffany & Co. display windows; being showcased in the New York Metropolitan Museum of Modern Art, posters for the San Francisco Opera and the Joffrey ballet. His ornate paper lanterns can still be found in smaller galleries and boutiques.

 

How the Funds Will be Used

This artist's hand-crafted works exemplify his love of distinctive design and turning paper into masterpieces. He has worked tirelessly for the love of his art, but the paper lanterns are labor-intensive, taking up to a week to hand craft from beginning to completion, and have become painful for Roy to produce now as a seasoned artist; yet he remains committed to sharing his awe-inspiring art with the world.

We’ve created computer files of Roy’s lantern designs and have made the prototypes.  All that is left is for the funds necessary to begin manufacturing.  Contributions will go towards the purchasing of materials and equipment that are required to produce Roy’s paper lanterns more efficiently and in higher volumes so that everyone can enjoy his life’s work.

Other Ways You Can Help

There are certainly other ways you can help this artist, any and all support is appreciated. We are socially connected and a firm believer in the power of word-of-mouth. Sharing via Indiegogo and other social media platforms makes it easy to promote the vision for this artist's awe-inspiring paper lanterns. Please connect with Roy Hoggard, LLC and help spread the word!

 

Comments or Questions?

Please use the comment section or email us: info@royhoggard.com  

Thank You to our contributers!

story:
I have been an artist and photographer for several years, carving my career and funding exhibitions as and when I have been able to do so. It has been a struggle to manage projects, raise funding and negotiate contracts. This is the same burden that all artists and creatives have when organising their first exhibition in the hope of being recognised and the exhileration of selling their first piece of work.

My aim with this campaign is to secure a permanent residence for artists to exhibit in the Sydney area. I am currently looking at leases and fit outs in the inner west areas of Sydney to open this business. The space will compromise of a fixed rotating exhibition, free exhibition space and photographic studio.

         

I will be the artist in residence carrying out all the daily operations with a permanent rotating exhibition space and will offer new and emerging artists free space and advertising to showcase their work. There will also be a functional photographic space which artists and visitors can use. New artists can be Australian or visiting from abroad, wanting to gain exposure in Sydney to further their career. So if you are from Europe, America or Asia and wish to add to your resume of work and exhibitions, you will be able to use the space to do so.

Most Exhibition spaces charge new artists a fee to rent space in a gallery, this can typically range from $300-$2000, they are also required to pay 30-40% of sales, this is not my aim with this venture. I will ensure the financial running of the gallery through my own art and photography and through a smaller commission on sales 25% from exhibitions.

In funding this project you will give Australian and visiting creatives the opportunity to showcase their work to the public and get a foot in the door.

Many artists are from disadvantaged backgrounds or suffer from mental or physical disabilities. Their creativity is their form of self expression and often depicts their view of the world around them which can be wonderfull, confrontational, vibrant and unique.

The money raised will go towards securing a long term lease on an appropriate property and a complete professional fittout to create a stunning new gallery space in Sydney. I will keep adding to this page over the following weeks and months as I explore suitable properties and ideas.

The Aim is to raise $50000 which will establish the Gallery and ensure its gets a head start plus the marketing/advertising it needs in the early days. We hope through your generosity to exceed and double this amount but If the total is not raised a smaller venue may have to be leased or the alternative of pop up gallery/exhibitions may have to be explored.

If you love photography, art or sculpture please contribute what you can, if your in a position to help with free advertising, marketing etc please support my campaign.

You can contact me at www.matthewlees.com

 

This is a Layout of the space I have in mind. Excellent street frontage and facilities, New artists get to exhibit their work at the front of the gallery on four 3 metre long rails and two easels. The photography studio is 2.1m wide by 5m long ideal for all sorts of photo shoots.

Please contribute generously.

Matt

story:
Ryan Clark

Investing in Ryan Clark is investing in a wonderful person. (Though as his wife I may be a little biased.) He works with kids in elementary schools and has spent summers working at Cub Scout Camp for almost 10 years. He is even the cubmaster for a nearby cub scout pack. He has a nickname of Bubbles or Mr. Bubbles, the name that thousands of kids now know him by. 

He is also a great artist. And very passionate about tattooing.

He has all the skills to be a great tattoo artist, he even has a tattoo artist willing to be his mentor. He has even drawn many tattoos for people over the years.(Including me!)The only problem is he doesn't have the money to afford the apprenticeship itself. 

This is an example of his work from high school!

What do we need?

The apprenticeship costs $5000.00 and requires buying the needed supplies.

This is one he drew for his wife!

What You Get for Helping Us!

What are the perks for helping Ryan?

  • The Cool! and Awesome! Perks Ryan will send you a drawing or full color picture.
  • You can suggest whatever you want! 
  • Or you can wait for a surprise and see what randomness you get!
  • Or for the Magnificent! and Crazy! perks you can get a full color drawing and a lock of Ryan's beard. (He LOVES his beard).
  • Finally for the Crazy! perk, Ryan will shave off his entire beard and send it to you, along with a full color drawing and pictures of before and after the shave!

He designed this at the request of a friend.

Other Ways You Can Help!

We are poor college students, we understand some people can't afford to contribute, but you can still help!

  • Spread the word!
  • Facebook, Tumblr, whatever works!

Thank you so much for anything and everything!

Every little bit helps!

Painting Ryan did for a friend. (Sorry about the bad photo)

story:
Thank you so much for checking out my Indiegogo project!

Here's the Deal:

I’ll be in the LoLa (League of Longfellow Artists) Art Crawl http://lolaartcrawl.com/ for the first time on August 24th and 25th.  Not only is this my first art crawl, it’s my first show since beginning painting again two years ago.  I’m excited about it and also a little daunted by the expenses involved. So I'm hoping to raise a little cash from you!

All money raised will be used to:

  • Frame artwork
  • Turn my office into a gallery for the show
  • Print greeting cards to sell
  • Print giclee fine art prints to sell
  • Print cards and posters to get the word out about my show at LoLa
  • Help the other expenses involved in putting a show together

What can you get for helping me out:

Greeting Cards of my art (Click on the 'Gallery' tab above to see images)

Giclee Prints of my art (You won't believe how amazing these look.)

Original art (These look even more amazing)

Check out the "perks" section to the right to see details.

If something isn't there that you want, let me know, I'll add it if possible.

The longer version if you want more background and info:

I'm seeking your support to show my paintings and drawings at the LoLa Art Crawl in August.  I've come back to creating art in the last couple of years after being away for a very long time.  I’m very excited to be in this place of joy that comes for me with creating these paintings and with sharing them with others.  I’ve been getting a lot of wonderful feedback from friends, other artists and teachers and mentors.  The next step for me is to show my work to a wider audience.  Since the LoLa Art Crawl happens right in my neighborhood with my office sitting on one of the main corridors, it was a no brainer to join the fun.

As with most new endeavors (especially in the art world), there are a lot of up-front costs involved with participating in an art crawl and selling my work.  Even with doing most of the framing myself, the costs add up fast.  I also need to pay for printing the greeting cards that will be part of the perks here and also available for sale at LoLa.  The same is true for the fine art giclee prints.  I’m so happy to have found a printer right across the street from my office who did an awesome job printing card samples for me and another small business a few blocks away that has done a beautiful job on scans and fine art prints.  So not only will you be supporting this local artist but also other neighborhood small businesses.

So yes, that’s where you come in, if you choose.  With this indiegogo campaign I'm hoping to raise at least $1000 to help with these upfront costs.  I’m jumping in with both feet to these times of crowdsourcing and social networking and we’ll see what happens.  I know the arts are not high on a lot of people’s radars these days but I believe they are an important part of keeping some balance in the culture we live in.  If you are familiar with the concept of CSAs (community supported agriculture) where people sign on, pay their money to support a local farmer and then get food deliveries from that farmer, you can think of this as Community Supported Art.  Choose what you want in your “box” from the ‘perks’ to the left (prints, cards or originals), enjoy some locally grown art and the feeling of satisfaction and generosity that comes with being a supporter of the arts.

Why would you want to support my work?  I only want your support on this project if you are interested in the work I’m doing or know someone it would be the perfect gift for.  I know it won’t appeal to everyone but if it does appeal to you, any amount of support is hugely appreciated.  If you can’t afford to help financially on this project, please help me out by spreading the word.  That will be a huge help to me!  Also if you are in the Twin Cities at the end of August please stop by LoLa to see the art in person or even to pick up your perk while enjoying some other artist’s work, too.

Thanks again.

Frame artwork
Turn my office into a gallery for the show
Print greeting cards to sell
Print giclee fine art prints to sell
Print cards and posters to get the word out about my show at LoLa
Help the other expenses involved in putting a show together

What can you get for helping me out:
Greeting Cards of my art (Click on the 'Gallery' tab above to see images)
Giclee Prints of my art (You won't believe how amazing these look.)
Original art (These look even more amazing)
Check out the "perks" section to the right to see details.
If something isn't there that you want, let me know, I'll add it if possible.


The longer version if you want more background and info:
I'm seeking your support to show my paintings and drawings at the LoLa Art Crawl in August.  I've come back to creating art in the last couple of years after being away for a very long time.  I’m very excited to be in this place of joy that comes for me with creating these paintings and with sharing them with others.  I’ve been getting a lot of wonderful feedback from friends, other artists and teachers and mentors.  The next step for me is to show my work to a wider audience.  Since the LoLa Art Crawl happens right in my neighborhood with my office sitting on one of the main corridors, it was a no brainer to join the fun.
As with most new endeavors (especially in the art world), there are a lot of up-front costs involved with participating in an art crawl and selling my work.  Even with doing most of the framing myself, the costs add up fast.  I also need to pay for printing the greeting cards that will be part of the perks here and also available for sale at LoLa.  The same is true for the fine art giclee prints.  I’m so happy to have found a printer right across the street from my office who did an awesome job printing card samples for me and another small business a few blocks away that has done a beautiful job on scans and fine art prints.  So not only will you be supporting this local artist but also other neighborhood small businesses.
So yes, that’s where you come in, if you choose.  With this indiegogo campaign I'm hoping to raise at least $1000 to help with these upfront costs.  I’m jumping in with both feet to these times of crowdsourcing and social networking and we’ll see what happens.  I know the arts are not high on a lot of people’s radars these days but I believe they are an important part of keeping some balance in the culture we live in.  If you are familiar with the concept of CSAs (community supported agriculture) where people sign on, pay their money to support a local farmer and then get food deliveries from that farmer, you can think of this as Community Supported Art.  Choose what you want in your “box” from the ‘perks’ to the left (prints, cards or originals), enjoy some locally grown art and the feeling of satisfaction and generosity that comes with being a supporter of the arts.
Why would you want to support my work?  I only want your support on this project if you are interested in the work I’m doing or know someone it would be the perfect gift for.  I know it won’t appeal to everyone but if it does appeal to you, any amount of support is hugely appreciated.  If you can’t afford to help financially on this project, please help me out by spreading the word.  That will be a huge help to me!  Also if you are in the Twin Cities at the end of August please stop by LoLa to see the art in person or even to pick up your perk while enjoying some other artist’s work, too.
Thanks again.

story:
This campaign is a super, rapid fundraiser; 

only 7 days! But we believe it is possible!


The (short) Story

About a year ago last week I, Chelsea Southard, began a relationship with a community of glass artists in Boston at Diablo Glass School. I came into the school one day in early July looking for candle holders, blue ones to be precise, I left with no candle holders but with a warm and welcoming invite to come back. So I did. At first I contributed to the school by doing photography, making promotional videos, giving lighting advice, and working on websites for the artists there. During this time I was also working on my own projects and installations, sharing my practice with them, going to college, and falling in love with glass, I was warned that would happen.

What blossomed out of this was an invitation to become a resident interdisciplinary artist at the school. I happily accepted and began my exploration into the medium of glass. I held a series classes and workshops at Diablo teaching students about sound, light, circuits, sensors and Arduinos, and how to  write code to be used creatively in art. Through the creation of a project inspired by my discoveries while working with glass and with the help of my students I have been teaching, along with the army of glass artists at Diablo; the culmination of this residency is to create a collaborative sound installation with glass as the primary physical medium.

This is the installation. 

This is the finale.

Concept

Things/Time (read Things over Time) is a public installation work in which human agency and its relationship to the material world is explored. The work will be installed within a simple mobile storage unit or POD. Through sound, light and technology the storage unit is transformed internally into an immersive chamber displacing the participant’s perception of the changing materiality of our environment through time, Decay, specifically related to that which divides space, our walls. This dynamic is both a present and powerful relationship as we study the growing community and urban renewal within Boston. The placement of this installation is intended for Berklee College of Music, for it’s central and iconic place in the social and physical landscape of Boston. It will be installed at 1140 Boylston St., outside of Berklee, from August 1st to August 16th.



Abstract

SOUND

The POD will be installed with a Quad sound system (4 speakers, one in each corner) which will play pre-recorded “sonic portraits” of 360 degree ambiances impulse responses and material and environment interaction taken the abandoned MBTA subway tunnels below Tremont St. in Boston, America's first subway tunnels ever built.

Since I will not have access to the tunnels until mid-July I have alternately been creating sonic portraits of locations within Massachusetts to mock up the sonic environment I am imagining. Below is one of the portraits I created using sounds sampled from Belchertown State School in western MA. 


GLASS

The technique that will be used for the glass pieces placed on the walls are done by method of overblowing glass spheres. By doing this and then breaking the bubble; delicate, angular and jagged glass pieces are formed. This aesthetic was inspired by peeling paint on a decaying wall; textural, fragmented and metamorphic. Also when lighting these shards of glass the imperfections of the glass reveal themselves as beautiful refractions of light and and texture.

Lots and lots of spheres will have to be made! But luckily I have the support of an army of glass artists willing to collaborate and contribute in the process of making these glass walls!



LIGHT

With the use of a variety of shaped and sized glass shards refractions of light will surround the inside of a movable Storage POD unit. This unit will be transformed internally into a chamber that captures the ephemeral nature of both mediums.

The landscape of glass diffusers will grow over the edges of the Pod internally onto the opposing walls and ceiling becoming a kinetic landscape in which the pieces of “fragmented wall" become active, showing movement and genesis through light. Kinetic action will be generated by servomotors and Arduinos.

During the day natural light will penetrate the inside of the POD creating natural optical refractions surrounding the space. And at night these visuals will be controlled by LEDs placed within the piece. 



The Impact

There has never been an art installment in a transformed storage POD of this kind in Boston or at Berklee. This installation will: 

  • Give the city a new public art experience; a single-space installation pop-up gallery in the form of an art pod
  • Give Berklee the experience of their first student-driven, large scale, public art piece
  • Raise social awareness of particular areas and buildings within Boston that are in need of protection and rehabilitation
  • Stimulate the forward-thinking of the community to begin improving such community spaces with appreciation for the beauty inherent in the history and meaning of even these decayed spaces

This installation will be a way of promoting “green-thinking” for the reuse of resources, attracting critical tourism, and of raising the public image of Boston based businesses and institutions past and present. Sustainability will be forefront in the project’s development and exhibition; metal used for the internal frame will be repurposed from Boston's Prospect Iron And Steel salvage yard, the wood will be reused from a demolished home and awaiting sponsorship, the site power will be from roof mounted solar.

This installation will give attention to the glass artistry within Boston and particularly to Boston’s Diablo Glass School, located in Roxbury Crossing. As part of Chelsea Southard’s interdisciplinary artist residency at Diablo Glass School she will lead a collaborative team of glass artists to assist in the creation of Things/Time. The artisans at Diablo will have the opportunity to learn and apply the world of technology-based art to glass, helping to further the knowledge of future artists in interdisciplinary works.

Sponsorship! And the Gaps that need filling.

We already have people behind us!

  • PODS Boston; donated the storage POD used for the installation
  • Prospect Iron and Steel; donating all the metal
  • Boston MBTA; access and support within the tunnels
  • You-Do-It Electronics; technology materials side of things
  • Berklee College of Music is lending us professional field recording equipment!
But we still need some funding for:
  • Transportation of the POD to and from location
  • The plexiglass for mounting the glass
  • Lots of epoxy resin for glass adhesive
  • Lighting!
  • Speakers for the POD
  • Hardware; screws, nails, tools, fasteners
  • Acoustical treatment

Other ways to help and get involved!

Come to the fundraiser on Saturday August 12th at Diablo Glass School! It will be night of food, wine, glassblowing, a silent auction and live music by some incredible Berklee Musicians, Sune and dmGida! Check them out!

SUNE

Boston-based duo Sune combines electronic sound, processed live vocals and generative visuals into an immersive multimedia experience.


dmGida

http://dmgida.bandcamp.com/releases 

http://acloserlisten.com/2014/07/08/dmgida-dwellmind/ 


Spread the word! Come to the opening on August 1st! We would love to meet you!


Photo Print Perk Options!

For a closer view on Chelsea's Flickr page click HERE!

story:
Our Story

South El Monte Arts Posse (SEMAP) is a collective of artists, writers, urban planners, educators, scholars, farmers, ecologists, swap meet vendors, and youth interested in engaging directly with the South El Monte and El Monte community through the arts by rethinking our use of space and transforming how we inhabit it. SEMAP will host “How’s the Water?” an interdisciplinary site-specific, public art exhibition on the streets of El Monte on the evening of July 27, 2011.

 

The title of this event comes from a parable in which two young fish swimming nonchalantly in their pond, are greeted by older, wiser fish with, “Good morning boys, how’s the water?”  Perplexed, the two young fish look at each other and one asks, “What the hell is water?”

 

One of the things this parable speaks to is awareness. Awareness of all the little and big, subtle and obvious (but especially the obvious) things that make up the water of the lives we go around swimming in. Not just politics, culture, and economics, but also the everyday/personal, eat, sleep, work, play, family and friends aspects of plain ol’ life.

 

For SEMAP’s exhibit, “How’s the Water?” seven artists have been invited from all corners of greater Los Angeles, to produce original photo and video work, site-specific installations and performances inspired by public spaces in El Monte and South El Monte. Artists Juli Grigsby, Jason Gutierrez, Romeo Guzmán, David Jovel, Lester Lawenko, Juan Renteria and Christopher Anthony Velasco are currently working on photo and video installations in local parks, freeway underpasses, blank building walls, alleys, gardens and vacant car lots, seeking to engage and dialogue with the community.

 

“How’s the Water?” will take place during and after a free community summer concert organized and hosted by the City of El Monte that will bring out hundreds of residents to a local park (Arceo Park). Every year, these popular events attract residents of all ages seeking to enjoy an evening of free music and food, as well as the shared experience of being part of a community gathered all at once in a common space.

 

The artists’ projects and exhibition will allow artists and local and visiting audiences to wake up from our often tedious and mundane lives and to focus in on all the sleepy blurred details. The feeling of the sun warming your closed eyelids, or having a conversation with someone who broke your heart, or of trying to make a really tough decision about how to live your life. In other words, The South El Monte Arts Posse operates on the belief that art can permit us to be human again. 

 

“How’s the Water?” projects include:

·      Public projected and printed photo and video installations

·      Freeway underpass “gallery” installation

·      Sidewalk performance of tourist’s living room slide show of visits to local historical, cultural landmarks

·      Improvised and choreographed bike performances by local and invited bike riders in abandoned car lots.

·      Hands-on instant t-shirt silk screening booth for residents

·      Printed catalogue that discusses artists’ process with community in making public work. The catalogue will be sold in La Casa del Hijo del Ahuizote (a cultural and archival center in Mexico City) and El Monte La Historia Society to raise funds for future SEMAP projects.

 

The Impact

Although only 20 minutes east downtown Los Angeles’ thriving arts scene, El Monte and South El Monte, a predominantly Latino, Asian and working class suburb, seems much further away from having any cultural and artistic experiences of its own. This under-resourced community counts on very little support for cultural events or arts encounters. SEMAP recognizes the cultural richness of this community and its artistic potential. “How’s the Water?” responds to this need.  In the future SEMAP will facilitate arts workshops for youth as well as talks, readings, and artist residencies. Your support will make all of this possible.

 

Although this is a relatively small community, it is part of a larger regional and global community that we are all a part of.  In early 2012, “How’s the Water?” will be exhibited and permanently archived at La Casa del Hijo del Ahuizote to facilitate dialogue across the US-Mexico border.

 

 

What We Need

Artists Materials/Equipment Rental:                                                                       

$100 allowance ($100 X 7 artists)                                                            $700

 

Catalogue

$7 per booklet ($7 X 50 booklets)                                                            $350

                                                                                               

Flyers

$150                                                                                                                $150

 

                                                                                                                         Total: $1200

 

Other Ways You Can Help

You can also support our event by coming out for some free art on:

July 27, 2011 7-10pm

3232 Tyler Ave, El Monte CA 91731


Forward details to friends via email, Facebook and Twitter. Check out our blog, Valley of Smokes, for artists’ bios, interviews and more project info.

story:
This elegant book is both a systematic study guide and a work of art. Detailing 5 of Elena's yoga classes available on YogaGlo, this book invites you to craft your own profound practices, and make your yoga your own. Explore sequencing, theming and your interior experience; then create your own well-wrought practices. 
You'll help us reach our project budget of $60,000; please enjoy our book and other offerings for your contribution.

Your funds will help produce, print and ship our book to teachers and yogis everywhere, including more than five hundred copies donated around the world to organizations training women, and specifically yoga teachers. Teachers in trainings from the Africa Yoga Project in East Africa to the Lineage Project in New York City will have the imagery and instruction in ART OF ATTENTION in order to create beautiful practices, both for themselves and for their students. 

Thank you for helping us make this book a reality. It gives us new reasons and ways to practice, and we're honoured to share it with you. 

We've been privileged to collaborate with gifted artists and photographers who love the practice; each sequence is rendered through their eyes.

Chapter 1: RELEASE TENSION AND FIND FORGIVENESS, captures our time at Black Rock Desert for Burning Man 2011. This visionary first chapter sets the tone for the entire project: a natural progression of healing practices that invite us to address ourselves and our worlds with less tension and more listening. Photographed by Michael Chichi

 

Chapter 2: LETTING GO OF BLAME, is a profoundly restorative practice, created in Elena's practice sanctuary in her home. This sequence is a refuge to boost our immunity, clear our minds and help us stay close to ourselves. Photographed by Chloe Crespi

 

Chapter 3: BREATHING AND MEDITATION, captured on the sun-soaked beach in Parrot Cay, Turks and Caicos, reveals emotions as simple energy patterns in the body; leading us to see, soften and heal through the practices of breathing and meditation. Photographed by Alice Marshall / Mandala Work by Sofia Escobar

 

Chapter 4: EXPLORE YOUR HIGHEST POSSIBILITIES, implores us to make a conscious choice to be of true service, in everything we do. Harlan Emil's art in the desert proved to be the perfect craft in which to cultivate this understanding. Photographed by Dominic Neitz and Michael Chichi  Art Installation by Harlan Emil

 

Chapter 5: YOUR PRACTICE MIRRORS YOUR LIFE, exemplifies the profound beauty of the teachings as we incorporate them into our daily lives. Captured in New York City, both the vast skyline and Elena's personal meditation spaces invite us to make art of our everyday landscape. Photographed by Dominic Neitz

Elena Brower is a mama, a writer, a teacher and a coach. She is proud to serve hearts and families on this healing path by making the teachings of yoga relevant and real. She's been teaching since 1997 and is honoured to teach at her home studio, VIRAYOGA, and internationally.

www.artofattention.com

Erica Jago is a gifted designer and artist as well as a teacher of yoga both in California and in Hawaii. Together Elena and Erica created this project to create context and spark conversation within ourselves about how, when and most profoundly, why we practice.

www.jagoyoga.com

Chapter 1: RELEASE TENSION AND FIND FORGIVENESS, captures our time at Black Rock Desert for Burning Man 2011. This visionary first chapter sets the tone for the entire project: a natural progression of healing practices that invite us to address ourselves and our worlds with less tension and more listening. Photographed by Michael Chichi
 

Chapter 2: LETTING GO OF BLAME, is a profoundly restorative practice, created in Elena's practice sanctuary in her home. This sequence is a refuge to boost our immunity, clear our minds and help us stay close to ourselves. Photographed by Chloe Crespi
 

Chapter 3: BREATHING AND MEDITATION, captured on the sun-soaked beach in Parrot Cay, Turks and Caicos, reveals emotions as simple energy patterns in the body; leading us to see, soften and heal through the practices of breathing and meditation. Photographed by Alice Marshall / Mandala Work by Sofia Escobar
 

Chapter 4: EXPLORE YOUR HIGHEST POSSIBILITIES, implores us to make a conscious choice to be of true service, in everything we do. Harlan Emil's art in the desert proved to be the perfect craft in which to cultivate this understanding. Photographed by Dominic Neitz and Michael Chichi  Art Installation by Harlan Emil
 

Chapter 5: YOUR PRACTICE MIRRORS YOUR LIFE, exemplifies the profound beauty of the teachings as we incorporate them into our daily lives. Captured in New York City, both the vast skyline and Elena's personal meditation spaces invite us to make art of our everyday landscape. Photographed by Dominic Neitz

Elena Brower is a mama, a writer, a teacher and a coach. She is proud to serve hearts and families on this healing path by making the teachings of yoga relevant and real. She's been teaching since 1997 and is honoured to teach at her home studio, VIRAYOGA, and internationally.
www.artofattention.com

Erica Jago is a gifted designer and artist as well as a teacher of yoga both in California and in Hawaii. Together Elena and Erica created this project to create context and spark conversation within ourselves about how, when and most profoundly, why we practice.
www.jagoyoga.com

story:
Hi! We are the APU Slam Team! 

As you might already know, we are a group of five women (and our coach Brian) who love to express ourselves through spoken word poetry.

We go to Azusa Pacific University and are really looking forward to competing in the College Union Poetry Slam Invitational this April.

This trip is, however, in New York this year... And you know how far Los Angeles is from New York...

which is why we are asking for your help! :) 

We participated in a regional competition this past weekend, hoping to get our nationals registration paid for if we had won first. We, unfortunately, placed second, and lost to first by 0.1 points.

Despite how bummed we were about this, we are hopeful that there is a reason why that happened. So now, we are leaning on our beautiful friends, family, and communities to help us out. 

As this is a national competition, we are representing our university on a pretty big scale. We are currently ranked 27th in the nation, are the only Christian university represented, and are hoping to do even better this year!

We are currently at $0.00...We just payed $200.00 worth of registration costs for regionals in Fresno out of pocket (which is ALOT, especially for broke college students :) ) and are hoping that you'll be able to help us out! 

What We Need & What You Get

We are trying to raise $4000 to cover everything - registration fees, transportation, meals, lodging, etc. 

  • Registration Fee: $750.00
  • Transporation: Flight ($362) x 6 = $2172.00
  • Lodging: ($300 - 2 rooms/per night) x 4 = $1200.00 400
  • Meals for five days for six people 

We know it's a lot to shoot for, but whatever you are able to give right now would be so helpful! Now, we'll get to the good part... WHAT YOU GET! 

$5: a shoutout on the APU Slam Team Facebook page

$10: a shoutout on the APU Slam Team Facebook page AND a hand written card from the team

$25: a shoutout on the APU Slam Team Facebook page AND a hand written card from the team AND a signed picture of the team 

$50: a shoutout on the APU Slam Team Facebook page AND a hand written card from the team AND a signed picture of the team AND a "keep calm and write poetry" tank 

$100: a shoutout on the APU Slam Team Facebook page AND a hand written card from the team AND a signed picture of the team AND a "keep calm and write poetry" tank AND a 30-minute set from the APU Slam Team & SuperB at any southern California location

The Impact

We truly believe that our lives are meant to be shared through stories, and poetry is our way of doing it. God has given us some amazing life experiences, and a voice to tell the world about them. Help us do that! 

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't financially donate right now, we completely understand! There are other ways to help! You can spread the word about what we're doing, and continue to keep us in your thoughts and prayers. Also, feel free to like us on Facebook at http://www.facebook.com/APUSlamTeam to continue being updated on our events and what we're up to! 

Thank you again so much for all your help. We wouldn't be able to do this without you!

story:
The current U.S. Congress is the most partisan in modern history.

The United States government's only hope of overcoming this divide is to inspire Congress to see past party lines, stop bickering, and compromise to do what's best for the country.  

The best, most succinct piece of literature I have ever encountered on the subject is Dr. Seuss' short story "The Zax", featured in the book The Sneetches and Other Stories.  In it, a North-Going Zax and a South-Going Zax bump into one another.  Each Zax refuses to get out of the other's way and both are hopelessly stuck in the same spot forever.  Sound familiar?  

I hope to try to remind our politicians of the importance of putting pride aside to compromise and do what's best for everyone by mailing every U.S. Senator a copy of The Sneetches and Other Stories.  

If I receive enough funding, I will also send a copy to each member of the House of Representatives. 

Note: I am not affiliated with the Dr. Seuss Foundation.

story:
We are raising money to bring the Buddha Lounge Music Stage & Theme Camp to Burning Man 2014. We are currently funding our Burning Man Theme Camp for 2014 by inviting people to camp with us on the Playa!  Help produce the Buddha Lounge and be part of our crew.   Check us out on Facebook! 

Buddha Lounge Facebook Page

We are offering amazing "Music Rewards" & remixes Desert Dwellers, Kaminanda, Govinda, Pumpkin, Kalya Scintilla, ChrisB., Dela Moontribe, Buddha Bass & Quade. Listen to Music Rewards: 

PLUS be the first to get live recorded mixes of live performances from the Buddha Lounge stage at Burning Man 2014.

http://soundcloud.com/soulfoodmusic

Buddha Lounge Theme Camp Mission Statement

The mission of the Buddha Lounge is to gift to the citizens of the playa the experience of music, sound and visual delights on the Esplanade creating close, interactive and intimate transformative experiences to those who venture by for a smile and a hug.  

and now.........

Top 10 Reasons to Camp with the Buddha Lounge!!!!!!

1. PRODUCER STATUS: Be a part of the production crew gifting the citizens of the playa with transformative musical productions, visualization display and amazing aerial and dance performances and Intergalactic Rocket Art Car. Live Performances by Govinda, Diva Danielle, ChrisB., Jobot, Buddha Bass & DJ Dakini.

2. WELCOME HOME: Place your home on one of the most prime and central locations at Black Rock City, located approximately at 9:00 and Esplanade we are placed near non-sound camps with an unobstructed view of The Man out our front door.  

3. HELP produce one of the most amazing musical line ups on the playa providing a high quality sound in a smaller more intimate space.  Your role is negotiable.  Not everyone has to work and there are many ways to contribute in the areas of video projection, trash clean up, feeding the workers, mediation/yoga guiding, performances, fashion, cooking, decorations, photography/videography, etc. 

4. ELEVATE your experience by partnering with experienced veterans that can guide you through everything from preparation, to how to get the most out of your time on the playa. As veterans we believe our responsibility starts well before the burn to help prepare first timers on all aspects of their participation to elevate everyone’s experience.

5. ART CAR The Intergalactic Rocket Art Car is space crystal jet racing across the playa taking you and 14 others to faraway destinations.

6. PARTICIPATE and or lead workshops on Yoga, meditation, fashion or whatever you want to share with others.  

7.  HOT SHOWERS!!!!  Take advantage of our shared shade space, shared shower stall with water evap, shared kitchen and communal breakfast supplies, plus several kegs of Modelo Especial on tap all week.

8.  CAMP with your new family and we will reserve your space and be there to help you orientate with you arrive.  We have Modelo on tap all week and a gourmet continential breakfast with organic granola, fresh fruit, vegan & gluten free options. You will know exactly where to go and how to find your space we saved for you.  24x7 power is also available per your arrangement with camp leaders.

9.  PARK your RV.  RV's are welcomed and will get reserved spaces, with accessible service lanes and 24x7 power is available per your arrangement with camp leaders.

10. Make your next best friends for life at the Buddha Lounge.  

MUSIC

The Buddha Lounge Sound Camp attracts international recording artists Emancipator, Desert Dwellers, Kaminanda, Pumpkin, ChrisB., Goldrush, Random Rab, The Human Experience, Quade, Jobot, Govinda, Sixis, Nico Luminous & Kalya Scintilla to perform inspiring & requiring us to offer impeccable Sound, Lighting & Video for the "Free Concerts!"  It's important to state that no $ goes to individual people as the Buddha Lounge is managed 100% by volunteers. All funds go toward producing our camp for this event: rentals, equipment, transportation & hard costs. 

Buddha Lounge sound camp has played at festivals including Burning Man, LIB, Gem & Jam, Lucidity, Serenity, Firefly, Bass Star & Sonic Bloom. 

For those who can't camp with us or experience our sound stage at Burning Man, you can still contribute to the project, starting at $5 with "Advance Digital Download" of Buddha Bass featuring Burning Man music headliners Kaminanda, Kalya Scintilla, Govinda, Desert Dwellers, Pumpkin, Dela Moontribe, Quade, Sattva Ananda, Mutiny & Sinoeh.  The Label Soulfood Music has agreed to donate 100% of their music proceeds to the Buddha Lounge. 

Camp dues will provide for much of our budget on the playa this year but this campaign is meant to supplement those resources and provide some great tunes to those who either want to be reminded of the good times at Buddha Lounge and say thank you, or who can't make it and want the good vibes to travel with them wherever they are. 

Burning Man Budget $15,000 but this is just the minimum and we can make the camp even better as the camp fills out. 

1. Stage, Sound & Lights $7k (Additional budget expands this plan) 

2. Transportation, trailers, trucks, fuel,   $4k

3. Power & Electrical  $3k (Additional budget expands this plan) 

4. Camp Supplies $1k (Additional budget expands this plan) 

10 Principles of Burning Man:

Radical Inclusion

Anyone may be a part of Burning Man. We welcome and respect the stranger. No prerequisites exist for participation in our community.

Gifting
Burning Man is devoted to acts of gift giving. The value of a gift is unconditional. Gifting does not contemplate a return or an exchange for something of equal value.

Decommodification
In order to preserve the spirit of gifting, our community seeks to create social environments that are unmediated by commercial sponsorships, transactions, or advertising. We stand ready to protect our culture from such exploitation. We resist the substitution of consumption for participatory experience.

Radical Self-reliance
Burning Man encourages the individual to discover, exercise and rely on his or her inner resources.

Radical Self-expression
Radical self-expression arises from the unique gifts of the individual. No one other than the individual or a collaborating group can determine its content. It is offered as a gift to others. In this spirit, the giver should respect the rights and liberties of the recipient.

Communal Effort
Our community values creative cooperation and collaboration. We strive to produce, promote and protect social networks, public spaces, works of art, and methods of communication that support such interaction.

Civic Responsibility
We value civil society. Community members who organize events should assume responsibility for public welfare and endeavor to communicate civic responsibilities to participants. They must also assume responsibility for conducting events in accordance with local, state and federal laws.

Leaving No Trace
Our community respects the environment. We are committed to leaving no physical trace of our activities wherever we gather. We clean up after ourselves and endeavor, whenever possible, to leave such places in a better state than when we found them.

Participation
Our community is committed to a radically participatory ethic. We believe that transformative change, whether in the individual or in society, can occur only through the medium of deeply personal participation. We achieve being through doing. Everyone is invited to work. Everyone is invited to play. We make the world real through actions that open the heart.

Immediacy
Immediate experience is, in many ways, the most important touchstone of value in our culture. We seek to overcome barriers that stand between us and a recognition of our inner selves, the reality of those around us, participation in society, and contact with a natural world exceeding human powers. No idea can substitute for this experience.

story:
Facts-

Just like the first campaign this is not a donation based campaign. When you choose your "Perk" you are ordering the products that Lawrence Lindell Studios are offering. By pre ordering the products in advance you are also helping me fund and create the products you are ordering (I know, STILL mind blowing!).


Why its important.
By setting up my own studio it allows me to be in a position where I will never have to compromise my art to make money nor go against my morals and values. By owning my own studio I can continue to push a positive light that is so desperately needed in this world and also empower my own people and others on a larger scale.

My studio will be 100% black own, which might not mean a lot to you if you're not black, but in our communities we don't own a lot of anything and as I get older I see how important it is that we have our own outlets that allows us to get our voices heard with out outside forces that could care less rather we live or die.

My studio will be 100% artist owned, which might not mean much if you're not an artist, but in the artist community we don't own a lot of anything either. We are always taught to work for others and never really understand how valuable and important our work actually is. We as artist need to invest in ourselves and each other so we can't be silenced nor pushed out. It's a gross pattern I see where people let artist build and create a magical environment, then take it away for their own selfish and money driven agenda. When we own our own, it's harder for them to do so.


What to order




Stickers





Buttons 





Prints



I Survived


Art Zines VOL 1-5



You're Beautiful VOL 1-3



Ink N Stuff

Romance N Stuff


Nice Hat


Original Art 


Art Book 4 Pack 

Color N Stuff


Werd 

Art in Transit 

Pen, Pad, Los Angeles 

Thank you for your love and support!!
Peace and love 
-Lawrence
